campaign.story:
THANK YOU TO EVERYONE WHO HAS BACKED THIS PROJECT! The minimum goal has been reached - and now it's time to stretch!
The actual budget for this project is significantly higher than what I've asked for here in this campaign - so, if you want to support Studio Te, or claim one of the rewards, now is a great time to become a part of making this happen!
I've added a new reward for this final week of the campaign - this T shirt! 
Available in all sizes, in limited quantities. 
Limited Edition Contact T-shirt, by Emma Kohlmann
to contact Greg Fox: ggddffxx@gmail.com
to contact RVNG: phil@igetrvng.com
PLAY

HELLO
I am turning my semi-professional home studio into an entirely professional and public-facing actual music studio operation, and I am asking you to help me make that happen. 
I'm offering all kinds of rewards in exchange for your financial contributions. Some examples include drum lessons, session work, and time at the studio itself (once it opens to the public). I'm also offering vinyl preorder and digital downloads of my new album Contact, which comes out on RVNG records in May. 
Thank you for your consideration and support.
Moving in
-THE STORY-
For the past three years, amid maintaining my parallel careers as a professional musician, teacher, and coach, I have been investing time and money into building a music studio in Brooklyn, NY. The space, while fully functional for recording, rehearsing, and education, is also the place where I live. I have always dreamed of establishing a fully professional studio that I could operate publicly, to help realize other musicians' creative goals as well as my own. 
In early 2020, the space adjacent to mine suddenly became available. The possibility of separating my living and working spaces, shifting the studio to an entirely professional, public-facing operation, became achievable. I did my research, made plans for a build-out, got the security deposit together, and took over the rent on March 1st.
the raw space
My initial plan for 2020 was relatively simple: make the necessary construction and equipment upgrades so that, when finished, the space would cater easily to all kinds of folks in various realms of music and sound - from bands looking to record albums, to voice-over artists who need a clean take, to soundtrack composers, and everything in between. 
After having numerous conversations with other musicians, engineers, and friends, I arrived at the notion that doing a Kickstarter could really help me get things off the ground. I put together a budget and a plan, with the intention to launch this campaign, and get things up and running while at home in between periods of international touring that I had planned for March through May. 
Then the coronavirus happened and, to say the least, everything became uncertain.

  Now we suddenly find ourselves in the grips of a global pandemic, and I've had to change course significantly. My touring year as of now is completely cancelled and/or postponed, it is still unclear. I was expecting, over the course of multiple rounds of international touring in 2020, to make almost all of my income from performance fees, merchandise sales, and teaching workshops. This would provide enough to cover both my home and studio rent and basic living expenses while I made the upgrades to the space and got it running. Once finished, the thought was that I would start bringing in clients, and the studio business would basically support itself. Now that all of my projected income as a working musician has pretty much evaporated, the plan to get this studio off the ground is somewhat in question, along to a certain degree with my livelihood in general. 
Literally every other musician, producer, engineer, and composer I know is in the exact same situation as far as this is concerned right now. 
PLAY

Why Now?
I believe that digging in and investing now in making this space a reality is the correct way forward. Not even a global pandemic will fully end the practice of recording music, and we will need spaces to facilitate that - especially ones where the day rate is not exorbitant, where there is a good, comfortable vibe, and where you can work with people who have weathered all kinds of storms that go along with living as professional musicians.
It is obviously a very strange time. I have reservations about doing anything right now that calls attention to myself, during this time of great global need and precariousness. While I am definitely struggling to figure out how to proceed, how to make money after having all my touring cancel suddenly, how to live among the daily multitudinous existential crises that we are all dealing with, I am also very hopeful. 
I wholeheartedly believe in the future of music. I believe in music's ability to bring us through and beyond crisis. I believe that we will find a way to get through this current one. I believe that many broken aspects of our society, which are currently coming to bear, will change for the better as a result of our overcoming such terrible and challenging events. 
Cancelling the plan for a new studio, backing down, feels like it would be the wrong move now.  I'd rather try to make this happen, in the face of... who knows? I'm choosing to be hopeful and optimistic, rather than accept defeat before even trying.
For all of these reasons, I am building this studio. I am asking you to help support me in this endeavor, to lay the foundation for something new, something hopeful. It is called Studio Te.
Jonah Rosenberg and Daniel Carter at Studio Te in 2019
What is Te ? 
Te (/də/; Chinese: 德, pronounced "duh"), is a key concept in Taoist philosophy, usually translated as "inherent character, inner power, integrity, moral character, virtue, morality, quality, virtue, merit, virtuous deeds." I've been a lay scholar of the Taoist cannon since I was 16, and when I started ever having to refer to this space by name, besides just calling it "my studio," the name "Te" always came to mind. 

The Functions of Studio Te
Studio Te will offer very competitive prices for tracking day rates in NYC. I have consulted with some of my favorite engineers and producers in the city to ensure that I can meet and exceed the needs of any type of recording situation, without needing to ask prohibitive day rates of my clients. 
Studio Te will also serve as the hub for my teaching practice and coaching work, where students and clients will come to find and dig more deeply into rhythms both internal and external. For now and the foreseeable future, these practices will be maintained in virtual space - but once this period of social distancing is finally behind us, I plan to have music makers, students, and clients from all walks at Studio Te on a daily basis - creating, exchanging ideas, learning, and expanding, sometimes outwardly, and sometimes towards the center.

 Contact – My New Solo Album
my new solo album, Contact, with art by Emma Kohlmann
Timing being what it is, I also have a new solo record coming out in May on the record label RVNG INTL - As of the time of writing this, the plan is still to release this music as originally scheduled and planned. Because of the alignment, we decided that it made sense to pair these initiatives - so, we are simultaneously announcing both this fundraiser and my new album, "Contact" (I swear I gave it this title over six months ago, without any idea that it would now take on very much added significance). The pre-sale for the album will be conducted here, directly, as one of the reward tiers. Some of the music on that album was recorded at Studio Te. The first single is below, the video animation is by Michael Flanagan, and the artwork comes from the inimitable Emma Kohlmann:
PLAY

RVNG Intl. will produce a limited edition color vinyl (blue!) exclusively for my campaign backers. We're aiming to make 200, but the pressing is scalable by demand. I just learned that the plant making this record is closed until April 19th – an unfortunate reality for vinyl pressing currently – so this LP product will not ship until June if we're lucky, July if we're being real.
My Story (As Told By Sasha Frere-Jones)
Any sound, repeated quickly, becomes a sustained tone. Any sound, slowed down, starts to beat. Music is the line between these two points, the wave that lives between the terminal ends of voice and drum. That’s where you’ll find Greg Fox. He moves through musical stages as both listener and player, a transformative rather than performative force. If you don’t know his work, start here: Fox is well-known in the lesser-known, a drummer with hundreds of credits on obscure records. His reputation is that of the elevated beast, that guy, the one who plays fast and loud and expresses himself at the extremes and in the extremes. That’s not wrong. Fox is also a slow theorist, a musician aware of those who came before him, and a teacher of drumming, with students all over the world.
PLAY

He remains a student himself, open-minded, honest, and willing. He has worked with drummers like Thurman Barker (Mighty Joe Young, Marvin Gaye, Cecil Taylor), Guy Licata (Drummers Collective, Jojo Mayer, Jim Chapin), Marvin “Bugalu” Smith (James Brown, Sun Ra, Chet Baker, Charles Mingus) and Milford Graves (Milford Graves). Fox has a practice that goes beyond drumming—he is a certified professional coach who focuses on transformational life changes. He helps people find their rhythms, in behavior, mind, and spirit. All of this experience draws to a point and that’s where you can find Contact.
Contact is built largely from the work of one person alone in a room, using his body to make sense of the surfaces around him. That was the reality when it was recorded in November of 2018 at Figure 8 Studios in Brooklyn. For obvious reasons, it is even more that now. Created in close unison with producer Randall Dunn, Contact makes the acoustic drum set talk and sing and see.
Fox uses sensory percussion to control and manipulate software instruments and samples. You’ll hear that on Contact in the washes of keyboards and bells and synthetic tonalities, all of it following the lead of the drums. It’s a record of rhythms that isn’t a beat record. Fox’s drumming is full and considered, like an enormous stone arm pushing slowly through a forest.
Contact occupies a space of energized meditation, neither mellow nor aggressive. It rolls the way Fox rolls. All of his musical experience flows into this record. If you know his past, you’ll understand his present. Fox has played with Liturgy, Zs, Ex Eye, Guardian Alien, Ben Frost, Colin Stetson, and dozens of other people. “I’m exploring collaborations now and using different guiding principles. I’m changing how I arrive at working with who I work with,” Fox said. “I’m engineering, teaching, and coaching. I’ve been operating and running a studio for myself, and it will be a for-hire studio very soon.”
PLAY

Thank you!
Thanks for taking the time to check this out. Wishing you good health, peace, happiness, and liberation, whoever and wherever you are.
XO
Greg Fox
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The major challenge of this project is that, to get Studio Te off the ground, I am doubling my monthly rent expenditure. Also, amid this global pandemic, keeping the rent covered while I get things up to speed here poses a formidable challenge. 

It's not just money issues that are a challenge now in light of the pandemic, but also time. It will take time to assemble all the materials and equipment, assuming there are no delays due to social distancing and businesses being shut down. It will take time and labor before the studio can be up and running according to my vision – and it will take time before people can physically and safely re-enter the world beyond their own spaces. Some delays may also occur around the production of some of the rewards I am offering. These are variables that I can't predict or control, but part of our current reality nonetheless.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
HELLO FRIENDS AND FAM
It's long past due that I update you all on how things are going here at Te, and speak to some of the delays in rewards being shipped.
First thing's first - a major apology is due. Basically everything is delayed these days, and I underestimated how long it would take for basically every reward to be created and fulfilled. I really appreciate everyone who has reached out directly to ask whats up and check in. Here are some specifics-

MY DEAR FRIENDS!
This Kickstarter campaign is officially OVER!
256 people very generously pledged a total of $19,604! 
I am so thankful that you believed in this project and wanted to help me make it such a success.
Back in February, opening a public-facing music studio very suddenly became an opportunity that I had to either seize upon quickly or let pass me by. I couldn't fathom the possibility of asking my community (nor for that matter the internet at large) for help. In my mind, this was something I wanted to do, so I had to figure it out for myself. A pivotal text exchange with my friend and colleague talking about the possibility of crowdfunding to help support the project changed that assumption, and the idea started to grow. People kept telling me, if I did this, that folks would want to support it. And then, at the beginning of March, all certainty bottomed out. Everything got cancelled, and all of a sudden we entered what is likely the strangest period of time in most of our lives so far. The decision to go forward with this campaign was a really tough one to make in the context of the pandemic, and the psychological and economic effects it had on everyone I know.

A quick, final update before the end of this campaign:
Kickstarter has extended the Studio Te campaign by a fews days because of... everything. So, I've decided that I need to spread the generosity around.
Half of the proceeds from every T shirt sale will now be donated to Artist Relief. This includes shirts that have already been bought.

The campaign to help fund Studio Te has been fully backed!
The outlined budget for all the work I'm planning on the studio far exceeds the amount that I set as the goal for this campaign, as you might imagine - so every extra bit helps tremendously. 
There are seven days left - and I've added a final reward:

TWO WORDS: THANK YOU
To all of the 156 people who have contributed to this campaign so far, either by claiming rewards or just giving freely - Studio Te will exist because of you! Thank you so much! We're at 95% - not far to go to reach the minimum goal. I so deeply appreciate all of the generosity, especially with the overall uncertainty that so many of us find ourselves wading through in this moment.

Just wanted to say thank you again, to the now 100 people who have supported this initiative! It means so much to have your support, especially during a particularly weird time to be running a kickstarter to begin with. One day this will all be behind us, and Studio Te will be flourishing - and it will not have been possible without your help.
Got some press for Contact and for the campaign in Rolling Stone! Did not see that coming.

Hi folks!
First of all... I'm so blown away by all the support so far. I certainly did not expect to be doing this well with the campaign in such a short amount of time. Thank you SO MUCH to everyone who has contributed to this campaign so far.
Lots of folks have been asking me if I am taking on new drum students right now. Since all of my touring and live gigs have been postponed or canceled through the summer, I am basically a full-time drum teacher and coach these days. So, the answer is yes! I'm taking on tons of new students. It has been really amazing to connect with so many drummers of all levels and go deep into hand technique and polyrhythm while we're all in this quarantine reality.
PLAY

project_data.project_name: Help Greg Fox open a recording studio in Brooklyn

campaign.story:
We're planning a festival!
Taking place in Cleveland, Ohio on June 4-7, 2020, the third annual Re:Sound New and Experimental Music Festival will provide a platform for the music of adventurous creators and performing artists of diverse backgrounds. Over the past two years, the festival has become an integral part of our city’s fabric, striving to highlight Cleveland’s strengths, address its needs, and facilitate meaningful connections between artists and audiences. 
Sound Energy performs at Re:Sound 2019
Re:Sound is run by Cleveland Uncommon Sound Project (CUSP), a 501(c)(3) nonprofit dedicated to promoting new and experimental music in Northeast Ohio. In addition to Re:Sound, CUSP also runs a year-round concert series and CoLab, an education initiative focused on cultivating the talents of local young composers who are nonbinary, gender nonconforming, or women. You can read more about the small but mighty team behind CUSP here. 
Leo Suarez performs at Re:Sound 2019
This is an artist-centered festival. Good music comes from happy musicians. As performers ourselves, we know how it feels to be taken care of. We book venues based on how they will showcase the artists we select. We are personally there every step of the way in soundchecks, and provide homestays for musicians coming from out of town.
We select performers through a call-for-performances that closed on October 1. Artists were asked to propose a set of 20-30 minutes of music that is either improvised or composed after 2000. This year, we had more applicants than ever before--almost 120! We will be making selections in late November, and booking venues soon after that. Past venues have included the Bop Stop (a jazz club), Praxis Fiber Arts Gallery, The Magalen (a DIY space in a century-old storefront), CODA Live Music Venue, and SPACES Gallery.
Elizabeth A. Baker performs at Re:Sound 2018
We are dedicated to building a community with Re:Sound, creating connections between artists from near and far and local audiences. The schedule includes plenty of group hangs throughout the weekend, and each concert presents at least two acts so that artists get to know each others' work. 
We also strive to make this festival open to as many audience members as possible. All of the venues at Re:Sound 2020 will be handicap accessible. And while we do charge admission, our prices have remained modest and consistent over the past two years. We charge $12 per concert and sell festival passes for $35. Discounts for students and seniors are available, at $8 for a ticket or $25 for a festival pass. No one is turned away for lack of funds.
Festival Timeline
We’ve already been hard at work organizing this year’s festival. Here’s what’s happened so far, and what’s coming up for us:
 Aug 15-Oct 1: Our call-for-performers was open to artists.
 Early Dec: The Re:Sound Committee meets and selects the  performers for the festival. Trust us, this is is SUPER HARD. There are always many more worthy ensembles than there are slots.
 Dec-Jan: We book venues and secure performer agreements.
 Feb: We announce the lineup and schedule.
 Feb-June: Preparations! Planning our advertising strategy, shoring up our budget, and fulfilling your Kickstarter rewards are among our activities in this busy time.
 June 4-7: The festival!
Popebama performs at Re:Sound 2018
We need your help! 
This year, we're hoping to grow in some pretty exciting ways. We'll be investing in things like increased performer payments, more advertising to grow our audience, and bigger venues to accommodate larger crowds.
Our total budget for the festival is just under $16,000, most of which goes to covering performer fees. We've already raised most of these funds through grants, individual donations, and ticket sales. About $1,000 of our Kickstarter goal of $6,000 will go towards fulfilling rewards and platform/credit card fees. Also, a note which may be important for some: while CUSP is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization and donations are tax-deductible, these Kickstarter donations will not be, due to the rewards we offer as a part of this campaign. For more information, please contact us.
Through Re:Sound, we're showcasing everything our city has to offer: enthusiastic fans, compelling spaces, and artists at the top of their craft who are passionate about sharing their work. We need you to help us reach new audiences and produce a weekend that is even bigger and better than any we've put on before. The musicians deserve it. The audiences deserve it. And Cleveland deserves it. 
So join us!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
There is a chance that renting larger venues and spending more in advertisements will not result in larger audiences. But we have so far been incredibly lucky so far in building a supportive community for new music in Cleveland, and our audience has steadily grown over the past two years. We feel confident in taking this risk. We also deeply appreciate the trust you are putting in us by donating to this campaign.

Concerts may not run like clockwork, or a freak Cleveland snowstorm in June could keep audiences away. But isn't navigating that tightrope walk the fun of live performance?
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Dear Kickstarter Backers,
With great sadness, we are announcing that Re:Sound 2020, slated for June 4-7, is cancelled due to the COVID-19 outbreak.
BUT there is a glimmer of hope!
We will be presenting this festival in 2021, with much of the same lineup and schedule. At this point, the majority of our acts have agreed to play. So mark your calendars for June 3-6, 2021 to join us in venues across Cleveland!

At midnight last night, our Kickstarter campaign wrapped. With donations from 81 of you, we were able to raise $6,410! We are so fortunate to be a part of this amazing community.
🙏🏼Thank you all 🙏🏼

Two words:
🥳FULLY 🥳 FUNDED.🥳
That's right, yesterday we hit our goal to raise $6,000 for Re:Sound 2020! Thank you to the 67 supporters who made it all possible.

You all have taken the time to help us out, even as the busy holiday season looms. Every one of you (that's 57 of you, to date) is a part of the CUSP family, and we want you to know how much your support means.
Thank you.
With eight days to go until Giving Tuesday, you all have funded almost 80% of our goal. That's amazing! . If we don't reach $6,000, we won't get of your donations.

Dear supporters,
It was cold and dark in Cleveland as I rolled out of bed this morning. I did what by now has become a daily habit, and checked our Kickstarter progress first thing. Over my steaming cup of coffee, I was overjoyed to find that overnight, we had broken $2,000, a third of the way to our goal!

updates.update_userinfo: One Week Down, Four to Go!
updates.update_content:
Dear adventurous listeners,
One week ago today was a busy day for us. In addition to welcoming Alia Musica Pittsburgh for our concert season kickoff, we also launched our first-ever Kickstarter Campaign, supporting Re:Sound 2020. As of now, we have received donations from 21 backers, totaling $1,133--a promising start, but we have a ways to go!

campaign.story:
OUR DEBUT EP IS FINALLY HERE! WOWZA! 
After 4 years of rebranding, we're very excited to announce the release of our first EP, Backpack of Snacks. This record represents years of work — writing workshops, tours, demo recordings, scrapping everything, more writing workshops, recording again. We've really given this project our all, and we're excited to get something physical into your hands. In order to make this dream a reality, we are hoping to raise $7,000. However, we set the goal at $1 because we need all the help we can get!


WRITING WORKSHOP - COLOR THEORY:
This EP is the result of our experimentation in color. Back in January of 2018, we decided that we wanted to see how our art would be transformed if we perpetually saw the world in different colors. Using this logic, we each wore various color-lensed glasses from the moment we woke up, the the moment we went to sleep. To create a catalogue of songs to choose from, we both demoed out 1 song per color. Once a song was drafted to a point of completion, we would move on to another color. We did this with 6 different colors: pink, yellow, blue, green, red, and orange. The result - Backpack of Snacks. 
All the glasses worn during color theory workshop!

WHAT TO EXPECT FROM THE EP?
This small collection of songs was inspired by colors (as previously mentioned) and music created by industry giants that we respect and admire. Each track offers you a different vibe, though, all of them should get your butt moving. We married our love of 80's synthesizer sounds and melodies with our love of hip hop and r&b.  We took those inspirations and sprinkled them with a splash of new life experiences such as starting our music over from scratch, getting married and moving to a new city. 
This record is a depiction of how we see the world and our attempts to to find peace, truth, and sustainability without diluting our creative spirits. Each song tackles issues like, proving your self-worth, experiencing failure, technological progression and resistance, and love (duh y'all, we're married - you knew we'd hit this topic). We hope that our sonic narratives help you as much as they've helped us. 

LIMITED EDITION BACKPACK OF SNACKS T-SHIRT
FRONT
BACK

FINKEL IS EINHORN - 5 PANEL HAT (Mock Image)
Our dear friend Sam started a company called Branded Bills a few years back. They create quality products that represent the people that wear them. Just like life, their hats change and get better with time and experience. Each hat tells a story and the logos are forged into various leathers with hot iron.  For real though, we wear ours nearly every day. We wouldn't be selling these things if they weren't an excellent product made by awesome people. Comes with a digital download of the EP. 

BE IN OUR NEXT MUSIC VIDEO (example below)

THANKS FOR YOUR SUPPORT! WE LOVE Y'ALL!

campaign.story:
The Neal Anderson Quintet is a five-piece modern jazz group that performs all-original music. We link together our compositions with improvisations to create a unique and seamless performance at each of our shows.
We recorded our first album, "Parallel Fifths," in 2015 (listen here: https://nealandersonquintet.bandcamp.com/releases). Since then, we've been experimenting with and developing our performance concept with new compositions.
We're ready to share these new compositions with the world - or even the galaxy - in the form of a new EP!
I'm thrilled to have Molly Jones (saxophone), Nathan Flanders (keyboards), Jon Hammonds (bass), and Cory Tripathy (drums) bringing their creativity and virtuosity to the music on this album.
Our new compositions are inspired by the idea that the music should dictate the form, instead of the form dictating the music. Each member of the band has the agency to dictate where a performance will go next.
Intertwined with an exploration of melody and groove in odd meters and phrase lengths, I think you'll find our music bothy catchy and refreshingly unexpected.
We recorded videos for two of our songs last year - one for the NPR tiny desk contest (watch here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P6VRVhV_aiA), and one in a public access TV studio (watch here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F8RMStXFtio).
In order to make a high fidelity recording of our music and properly compensate everyone working on the album, we need your support!
Between studio time, compensating the musicians, and producing the CDs, I expect the total cost of this project to total $3,500.
We've scheduled studio time in May and will be mixing, mastering, and pressing this EP over the summer. With your help, we hope to share this music with you the end of the year!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
As an independent musician, it is a challenge to professionally record and share your music. Bearing the up front costs of recording, mixing, mastering, production, marketing, and musicians' time can be a significant financial hurdle.

I expect the total cost of this project to total $3,500 - broken down as follows:
Recording, Mixing and Mastering: $1,500
Musician's Compensation: $1000
CD Production and Cover Art: $1000

I hope you find this project as exciting as we do. Your support is more than a pre-order - it provides the means and motivation to enable us to pour our creativity into this music. Together we can make this album a reality.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
Intro
Enter Branch is an album and multimedia project inspired by growth, vulnerability, and community. Set in place by the 2016 project Rushing Past Willow (successfully funded here by you), Enter Branch is the next step building upon its message and visceral sound world. While Rushing Past Willow was the culmination of years of artistry, there was still more to explore.  Pieces that were once impossible to perform due to their sheer physicality and virtuosity necessary are now fully realized in Enter Branch.
Kickstarter functions on an all-or-nothing model.  Either we raise the full amount of this campaign, or I get nothing.  While this might seem like a HUGE gamble, I think it conveys just how passionate I am about the project. I'm already all-in with this one, and if you read on, you'll see why.
Collaboration
The project comprises my own compositions, but this time, I'm not alone. Enter Branch combines my solo performance with inspirational artists who believe in the same message of vulnerability and community. Enter Branch includes collaborations from:
Sean Carey (S. Carey, Bon Iver) co-composing/vocals
Nathalie Joachim (Eighth Blackbird, Flutronix) co-composing/vocals
Brian F. Joseph (mix engineer for artists including Bon Iver, Sufjan Stevens, S. Carey, Paul Simon, and many more) mixing
Casey Foubert (Sufjan Stevens, mix engineer, multi-instrumentalist, song-writer) mixing and co-composing
 ~nois saxophone quartet, collaborating musicians
Devin Drobka (Field Report, Lesser Lakes Trio, Yins) percussionist, collaborating musician
Tontine Ensemble improvising string quartet, collaborating musicians
Amy Petrongelli soprano, collaborating musician 
Galen Bundy (Project 206, Groove Plexus, pianist) collaborating musician
Aleks Tengesdal cellist, collaborating musician
The collaborators communicate not only through their artistry, but also through community engagement. This strikes a chord with me. This project extends far beyond an album, creating branches between different communities. These musicians have dedicated so much of themselves to this project. I’m truly humbled by their belief in Enter Branch. This campaign will fund a wide release that does their artistry justice.
Recording
All tracks have already been recorded and mixing is about to begin! Excerpts of the compositions are even included in the Kickstarter video. While recording has been a long process (almost 18 months!), it is just the beginning of the journey. Mixing and mastering  is next, which is a long (and expensive!) process.  Following that, the Enter Branch project will include an album release and video productions. I need your help in order to fully realize this endeavor.
Thankfully, I've worked as a recording engineer for the past 10 years, and much of my research as a doctoral student focused on experimental microphone techniques for saxophone.  This covered a potentially HUGE chunk of funding that would otherwise be necessary. But, mixing and mastering are different art forms. I'm seeking the help of mix engineers to fully realize the compositions on Enter Branch. I'm positive that their artistry will bring the compositions to a level that I wouldn't be able to imagine on my own.
Videos
Similar to Rushing Past Willow, the compositions of Enter Branch unfold as a narrative, not so different from cinema. Already, I've learned so much about pairing video with my music (you can see examples here). Enter Branch will continue in this multimedia endeavor. In the end, at least of half of Enter Branch's compositions with have a visual counterpart. 
However, video productions are an INCREDIBLY expensive pursuit!
Even when I'm serving as the director of photography, financial support is needed for equipment costs, venue rental, props, actors, and financial support for crew members. But, that's just one part of the puzzle. 
Enter Branch will build upon visual collaborations found in Rushing Past Willow. While the former project mainly concentrated on dance film, I plan to commission films, animations, and potentially virtual reality endeavors that expand the narrative. Additionally, I will use my own skills in film-making in this endeavor. These visuals will be released online throughout the year after the album release, free of charge for all to enjoy on their own terms. Similar to Rushing Past Willow, I intend to perform with many of the videos in live concerts.
Release
Rushing Past Willow was a fantastic success, reaching audiences around the world, garnering accolades from major press (Wall Street Journal, Huffington Post, Pop Matters, and many more, along with national and international awards for film). 
The previous project was limited by one thing; financial resources. The printing of albums, label fees, production, and PR are some of the most costly aspects of releasing an album. While I’m immensely proud of the work that Rushing Past Willow put into the world (especially considering the bare-bones budget), I’ve learned a great deal from the experience. While this was new during RPW's release, I now have a much stronger understanding of how the process works.  Now I need the means to do it.
Your financial support will directly allow Enter Branch to reach audiences of all kinds, connecting us through a common message and musical experience.

What you are funding
In order to fully realize this project, I need to raise $20,000. These funds will cover:
$7000 covers initial PR costs
$4500 label fees
$4000 towards mixing/mastering
$500 towards the creation of cover art
$4000 video production and collaboration
In past decades, when the record industry was at its peak, a major label would cover these essential costs and aid with publicity pursuits. But, the nature of the business has shifted. I'm excited and eager to pursue this project on a much larger level. Your donation will help Enter Branch reach new ears, connecting people through an experience of grown, vulnerability, and community.
Exciting Reward Tiers!
Over the past few years, I have used my work as a media artist to fund many of my projects. Enter Branch is going to create this same dynamic!  Your donation at many of the "Media Level" tiers will both help YOU acquire some excellent media by yours truly, while also making this project a reality. KEEP AN EYE OPEN FOR SOME SPECIAL POP-UP DEALS THROUGHOUT THE CAMPAIGN!

We Can Do This!
There has been an unparalleled amount of love, time, and financial resources invested into this project. The pieces have already touched the lives of audiences in live concerts, and it is time to share them on an even wider scale. Rushing Past Willow exceeded the reach and expectations of everyone involved. Functioning on a skeleton budget, the project changed lives.  This time, we’ll do it right. I can only imagine the impact that your contribution will have.
Stretch Goal
This is dreaming big...but I would love to pursue another part of this project.  I recorded these tracks and engineered them, but the thing is...as soon as the music is out in the world, it's not mine anymore.  It's ours.  I'd like to investigate that further with a sort of "remix commissioning" project.
If we get past the $20,000 goal, the funds will be split two ways.  First, additional proceeds would go to additional visual projects.  Second, I will look for mix artists, DJ's, EA composers, etc, and commission remixes from them, giving them free reign over the audio from the tracks of Enter Branch.  I would LOVE to hear your feedback on this!  Do you have people who you want to remix this music?  If we get into the stretch goal, let's talk!
If we made it to the stretch goal, I would commission these remixes and put out an Enter Branch Remix album as a digital-only release.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
For the past 18 months, I have been recording these compositions. These pieces are the culmination of years of composition and practice. At this point, the compositions feel communicative, authentic, and ready to be shared. Though it was no simple task to align schedules and find times and places to record, all guest artists have already recorded their parts, and mixing has already begun. The rest of the process lies in post-production and the creation of the visual component. To ensure the completion of the project, I’ll be confirming the commitment of a solid team for the release (label management, PR personnel, etc). One thing that I’ve learned from Rushing Past Willow was the sheer amount of time and planning needed in order to have a successful release. If delays occur, it will only be in order to carefully plan this project’s trajectory. I’m working to create the absolute best product possible, and we will go through revisions until the composition is resonating with all parties. But at this point, the necessary foundation is already in place for Enter Branch to succeed.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
This is it. We're in the Endgame now.
(...no, I couldn't resist the Avengers reference)
Here we are, in the final week of the Enter Branch campaign. With your support, we have already raised almost $12,000!  While there is still a gap to fill, let's look at this from another perspective for a moment. Rushing Past Willow raised $5,000 in 30 days. Already, Enter Branch has almost tripled that amount, and we're not done yet! I think this shows just how much of an impact Rushing Past Willow has had. The music connected people, and Enter Branch will grow from this message. Your support is going to make this a reality!

campaign.story:
THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!!! WE MADE IT TO OUR INITIAL GOAL OF $1800!!
Because of you, we have those essential items of our budget (listed below) covered! The next thing funds would go to support is our survival on the road - we'd love to not rely on ticket sales for our meals/lodging costs/etc, and we're one step closer to being able to do that! Plenty of zines/prints/tickets are still available!
Visions for the End of the World is a solo theatrical performance developed by me, Scott Crandall.
In 2015, I began writing the first poems that over the next two years would be developed into the performance. In 2017, the piece premiered with the support of Monty Etzcorn as a co-designer and technician. Now, we're gearing up to take the next step: a tour around the Midwest and the East Coast, a series of original linoleum block prints, and a zine that includes text written for the project. 
Image from early (2016) work-in-progress performance
The Zines and Prints
From the earliest writings, "Visions for the End of the World" was always meant to include visual/written material as well as a performance. Through my collaboration with Monty, that's finally going to happen. 
We're releasing a zine that includes text that is either in the performance or was written as a part of the development of the show digitally overlaid on eco-prints that Monty developed.   
Alongside the zines, we're producing a series of three original linoleum block prints inspired by images from the show. These visual materials will help to make subsequent productions of "Visions" financially feasible by selling them at performances. Here are the three relief print designs:
The Tour
So far, "Visions" has been performed about 15 times in full, and always in Michigan. This tour will include roughly 20 performances across 10 states, and show the work to hundreds of people. Over the course of two 14-day trips between May and July, we will show the piece at about sixteen unique venues. 
The tour will kickoff with two weekends of performances in Detroit - the first weekend will be May 17th and 18th at Spread Art in Woodbridge, and the second on May 24th and 25th at ANDY on Fenkell. Tickets to these performances are available in the rewards.
The Midwest Loop!

The Budget
$1800 gets the project into the air, and helps to cover the up-front costs of getting everything together. Here's the line items we need to cover to make this thing happen:
- Raw Materials for Zines & Prints:       $675
- Gas:                                                           $350
- Space Rental:                                         $300 
- Sound Equipment:                                 $225   
- Lighting Equipment:                              $100
- Kickstarter Fees:                                    $150
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Though we have lots of experience producing and self-producing performances, and with putting up "Visions" in a short amount of time or in unconventional spaces, we don't have any experience with touring. So some things will probably go wrong with that aspect, and we'll have a chance to learn from those challenges and avoid them in the future.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
Microliths is my first album.  I'm excited to have recordings of jazz compositions I wrote between 2009 and 2016, performed by some of the best musicians and people I know.
This band has three basses. And they sound big and wonderful together.
Molly Jones, tenor and soprano saxophones, flute, compositions
Marcus Elliot, tenor saxophone
Derek Worthington, trumpet
Betsy Soukup, bass
Ben Willis, bass
Ben Rolston, bass
Jon Taylor, drums
Josef Deas recorded the album at Big Sky Studio in Ann Arbor.  He's a Master Engineer and Acoustic Sorcerer; his expertise, ears, knowledge, and flexibility have made the process joyful and the music sound so good.
The album circulates around melodies, structures, thorough-composed sections, and open improvisation.  Some of the tracks are jazz tunes I wrote in college.  Some of them are more recent compositions.  Some are based on traditional Shaker music making.  All of them express tidbits of the rhythms and songs that go through my head all day.  I'm happy to be able to share them.
I landed on the concept of micro-liths because it expresses fragmentation, diminution, and solidity.  Microliths are prehistoric tools: tiny, sharp, intentionally carved pieces of stone.  Their specific functions aren't known, other than that they were probably useful for small household tasks, and they were sometimes glued into bunches to make nasty spears.  I hope this music is in some small way enjoyable to you and that a few rhythmic or melodic ideas stick with you.  This album captures some of my musical fragments, in a few of their many iterations through time.
In addition to time, effort, rehearsals, coordination, and listening, creating this album takes money, which is where you come in!  I hope you will consider donating.  I'd like to make Microliths available in CD format and on Bandcamp.  I've made other things for you that you can have if you donate more, too!  Bonus tracks, a zine, your very own microlith to be performed at the TBD album release...  The album still needs to be mastered, printed, and distributed!  I'd really appreciate any help you can give in getting this project off the ground, and I very much look forward to sharing the music with you.
You can hear the band live at Solstice Jazz Festival in East Lansing on Saturday, June 24, and at a TBD album release party if this campaign is successful!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
I'm new to producing albums, so the process of creating art, printing, and distributing will be a challenge to me. If anything delays the creation of the album, I will inform all backers, and I may enlist a designer to help with packaging.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content: All the rewards have been sent, so if you haven't received yours or there are problems, please contact me!

CDs are in, zines are printed, projections are ready, wine is bought, and there's visual art from Jake Shadik, Ben Willis, and Frances!  Also, stickers :-)
Please join us on Thursday, 8 pm, at SpreadArt, 5141 Rosa Parks Blvd, Detroit.  Cover $5-10 sliding scale at the door, and those who donated to get an album and zine can pick them up!  Those who donated to get your own mini-piece written will get to hear it, and those will also be video-recorded for the folks who can't make it to the show.

The album is at the printer, zines are coming, stickers are coming, and visual art is being gathered to put up in the gallery on 9/7.  Thanks so much for the continued interest and support; I hope many of you can make it!

It's finally time for the Microliths release show!  It will be happening on Thursday, September 7 at 8:00 pm @ Spread Art, 5141 Rosa Parks Blvd, Detroit.  I'm excited to present the music and the 14 mini-pieces I've written for you!  I'll also have a few visual pieces on display in the gallery.  Cover $10, music starts not too long after 8:00.
If you requested a physical copy of the album, you can pick it up from me at the show.  Otherwise I will mail it.  CDs will be available for sale, as will copies of my zine of poems, Moon Jar.

Microliths is in the mastering process!  The sounds are in the expert ears of Josef Deas. I'm hurriedly composing micro-pieces for fifteen of you and finalizing album art.  Stay tuned for the album release show date, late August or early September!

I'm excited to bring you this music! Thank you so much for making this album happen! Now it's time to have the recordings mastered and printed. Once there's a timeframe in place for that, I'll start planning the album release show! Stay tuned!

Thanks to all of your amazing generosity the album is happening!! I don't have the words to express how lovely this is and you are. Thank you so much!
I now have to go do things like get it mastered, finish the art, and write a bunch of micro-pieces as rewards, and once that's done, there will be an album release show for Microliths in Ann Arbor or Detroit! Stay tuned.

There are three days left to go! I am blown away by the generosity and interest in this music shown by all of you. I'm really hoping to bring this album to life, but first I need to push through and raise enough to finish the album! I'm hoping it will happen. 
We had a great set at the Solstice Jazz Festival in East Lansing on Saturday, sharing the stage with BassDrumBone, David Murray, and Kahil El Zabar. It was a good time and an honor! I'm hoping to perform this music more in the near future. But first...to finish the album.

The campaign is halfway over, and it's just over half funded!  Thank you so much to all the amazing people who have supported the album!!!  I am grateful for each of you.  I've met you in different places and situations, and you've been such good people in my life, and I know pretty much all of you personally.  And in addition to being good people, you are helping me out so much with the Kickstarter support!  Thank you!
The rest of June I will still be blasting the campaign.  I can't release the album without these donations, so I'll be plugging it right up until June 30.  Thanks for the re-posts, the shoutouts, etc.!  I can't do any of this music release stuff without you, and it's such a blessing to have your help!

campaign.story:
We are OrnâmatiK, a band out of Ann Arbor, MI that brings you original compositions, infectious grooves, and unique interpretations of Eastern European folk music. In 2012 we released our debut album as a larger ensemble with all traditional songs. Since then, we developed our sound, stripping down to the bare essentials and blending the spacious combination of three live horns and drums & bass with electronic effects and vocals. We continued our exploration of music from the Balkans and, most excitingly, spent countless hours writing and rehearsing new compositions that we are ready to record and share with the world! Our current lineup consists of the visionary Drew Schmieding on drums, the lively Ben Rolston on bass, the experimental Derek Worthington on trumpet, the improvisatory Eric Schweizer on reeds, and the intuitive Bethanni Grecynski on trombone, kaval (Bulgarian shepherd's flute), and vocals. 
THE PROJECT: About This Campaign 
We cannot wait to share this music with you. We are extremely proud of the unique compositions we've been working up and the distinct sound we've developed as a band. But there are many costs involved in producing a record, which is why we're asking for your support. The money we raise here will go directly to pay for the costs of this project:
studio expenses 
engineering
mixing
mastering 
artwork 
design 
manufacturing
Your support will bring our vision of this music to life! The album and all the rewards offered in this campaign are original - including CDs, vinyl, drawstring backpacks, aprons, and more - and we know you'll enjoy them. Certain items will require a decision of color or design so we'll get in touch after we've been sucessfully funded (fingers crossed). Bethanni and Ben are in the process of creating amazing artwork which will be featured on the album and the rewards. 
Throughout this process we've been working with some truly inspiring recording engineers, Rishi Daftuar and Don Godwin. Their dedication and craft are showcased in each of the songs you'll hear on the record.
 THE MUSIC: Hear Examples From the Album Setlist 
The following tracks are demo rough versions of songs we intend to record on this exciting second release. They represent the basic structure of each song to offer perspective on what you can expect, but the final versions will be much more warm, full, and sonorous.
Balkan Space Camp
 Kromanica
 Hedcek
OUR PREVIOUS RECORD:
ITEM MOCK UPS:
Laptop Bag Mockup

This will be the first time we've released an album on vinyl, which offers its own unique challenges in terms of mixing, mastering, and printing. We're also releasing almost all original music, which is new for many members of the band, and offers its own risks in copyright and registration.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Hi everyone,
We hope that you all are staying safe and healthy in these uncertain times! 
Due to the Michigan executive order and our shipping materials being divided between residences, the shipping of "Tickles Brains and Feet" has been delayed (again). If you received a digital download, we will gladly send you your download code to your email address.  Once the executive order is amended to include meetings of individuals outside your immediate residence, we will ship them out ASAP.

Hi everyone,
Thank you all for your support and communication regarding the project! We have finally received our vinyl copies of the album and are shipping rewards to our out-of-town backers in the next couple weeks! We have hand delivered rewards to most of our local backers. If you haven't received yours, be on the look out!

Hi everyone,
Thank you all for your continued patience and support of this project! We love you!!!!
We have the final master of "Tickles Brains and Feet" and are excited to share it with all of you! We are beginning to place orders for all of the rewards and just wanted to remind everyone to fill out the surveys for addresses (might need to update to a more current one... as the wheels of creativity grind slowly!) and t-shirt sizes.

Hi everyone,
Wow, what a whirlwind! After many late night mixing sessions and getting edits from musicians around the country, we finally have finished the mixing process! Everything sounds great and will be sent off to be mastered ASAP, then printed! 
We apologize for the huge delay and we want to let you know we value your support. Every backer will be receiving a copy of our debut album, "Ornamatik," along with the other rewards they donated for, so look for that soon.

Hi everyone!
Thank you all for your patience throughout this whole process. We're almost finished with everything for this project; we've been laboring on getting things just right before we release it! With the art complete, we just have a few tweaks to the tracks to make then off to the presses and into your mailboxes!

Hi everyone,
Happy New Year from Ornamatik to all of our backers and fans! Just wanted to update you on the processes we're involved in and give you some idea of a timeline on when the album will be released.
Recently we invited some guests to appear on some of the tracks from the album and are arranging getting them recorded remotely (some here in Michigan, others in NYC and Nashville). Once we have gotten their recordings, we can get the final mixing from Rishi and mastering (plus extra mastering for that oh so sweet vinyl) from Don completed. From there we can get it all printed up and sent right to your doorstep for you to enjoy whenever you want! A good estimate would be a Spring release.
PLAY

THANK YOU SO MUCH! We are massively grateful for your generous support. We'll be back in the studio on the 23rd, then on to the process of mixing and mastering. We'll keep you updated as to our progress, and we'll get the final product to you as soon as we can. Thanks again!

updates.update_userinfo: Video Update - Behind the Scenes Recording of "Sandansko"
updates.update_content: As our campaign gets into its final 5 days, we wanted to share a behind the scenes sneak peak of one of the tracks off the new album: Ornamatik's original arrangement of a Balkan traditional entitled 'Sandansko Horo!' This footage was taken by master videographer Troy Anderson during our recording session in May and we wanted to share it with our fans and backers so you get a taste of what Ornamatik has been working on these past few years. Hope you enjoy it! Please continue to spread the word about our campaign and let's bring this project to life through the support of our family, friends, and community! Only 5 days to go!

campaign.story:
The 2nd Annual A2 JAZZ FEST
Sept 8-9, 2017 Ann Arbor Distilling Co. Ann Arbor, MI Free! 
A FREE 2-Day Community-based Jazz Festival, on Sept 8th & 9th 2017 in Ann Arbor, Michigan,  the A2 JAZZ FEST will bring multiple generations of local jazz artists together with a supportive community of fans to create a great celebration of Jazz in Ann Arbor. 

About this ProjectWe at the A2 Jazz Fest are raising funds to cover costs for our 2nd annual jazz fest to be held on 9/8/17 from 7-10pm, and 9/9/17 from noon-8pm at the Ann Arbor Distilling Company, Ann Arbor, Michigan. To ensure the successful hosting of our FREE, community jazz festival, we need your help with costs that include musician compensation, sound equipment and engineers, advertising and operations costs (posters, volunteer support and clean up).

The A2 JAZZ FEST’s mission is to showcase and promote jazz by presenting live performances of original compositions and jazz standards by Michigan based artists. Organized by Ann Arbor bassist, composer and band leader Dave Sharp and a committee of dedicated volunteers, (http://www.davesharp.com) the A2 JAZZ FEST grew out of the weekly jazz series at the Old Town Tavern in downtown Ann Arbor, which began in November of 2014.

Nestled in the heart of the Water Hill neighborhood of Ann Arbor, the A2 JAZZ FEST will light up the Ann Arbor Distilling Company on Friday September 8th and 9th, with an eclectic line-up of some of Ann Arbor’s most exciting Jazz performers, representing a multi-generational commitment to the art of Jazz music. Our FREE community festival will showcase a phenomenal line up of artists that includes both established musicians and students from middle school right through to University level. This is in keeping with the A2 Jazz Fest’s commitment to provide spaces and opportunities that organically foster musical mentoring relationships between musicians. Festival supporters can expect music for every taste, from traditional well-loved standards to original compositions and explorations of important life themes. 
We hope that you will partner with us through making a financial contribution, sharing the Kickstarter with others and attending the festival with friends and family. Thanks for considering our project!!
-the A2 JAZZ FEST Team
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The risks of this project are poor weather conditions and the University of Michigan football game interfering with the festival. There is rain cover within the structure of the Ann Arbor Distilling Co, and the event is on the north side of downtown Ann Arbor, opposite the football stadium on the south side of Ann Arbor.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

Greetings A2 JAZZ FEST BACKERS!
THANK YOU for supporting the A2 JAZZ FEST! With 11 HOURS to go, we are at 79% and it keeps climbing. Keep in mind KICKSTARTER crowdfunding campaigns are all-or-nothing campaigns, so we get zero funding if our goal is not met by 11am on Saturday morning.
HOW CAN YOU HELP?

campaign.story:
Please note: "Guest" backers appear as anonymous
Please take the extra minute to create a kickstarter account instead of pledging as a guest, so that I can know who you are and thank you personally! Otherwise I will not see your name until after the deadline. 
The Album
The song playing in the video above is Oh, What A Morning (it fades out before the final verse). It is just one of ten songs that will be featured on this album. I've been performing these songs locally over the last two years and now I'm so excited to get them out there for the rest of the world to hear!
The album was home-recorded by myself and has been mixed by Adam Krinsky of Bellows Studio in St. Paul, MN. The next steps in the process will be to get the album mastered, design the artwork, and send it off for replication.
The Cost of Producing this album
The true cost of producing this album is far more than my goal of $6000. I am seeking funds to pay only for the mixing, mastering, and replication of 1000 CDs. Here is a breakdown of the costs for which I'm seeking support through this Kickstarter: 
Mixing $3000
Mastering $1000
Graphic Design $500
Manufacturing of CDs $1500
Costs I am covering myself are: Recording gear ($3500 including computer, software, interface, microphones), the sourcing and assembling of rewards ($1000 for zine copying, T-shirts, prints, etc.), and Kickstarter fees (approx. 8%-10% of total pledged amount so at least $480). 
Some notes about the Rewards: 
The Art Zine (pronounced 'zeen') is a small photocopied booklet (mini-magazine) of original sketches, musings, photos, & text. For this Kickstarter project I will be making a special new zine available only to backers. Each one will be signed. Here are some pics of the cover and inside pages of a previous zine I made: 
Cover and pages from my first Ingeborg von Agassiz zine, 2015
About the 8x10 Art Prints: I am also a painter and these prints are of a few of my favorite acrylic paintings I've made in the last few years. Prints will be unmatted and unframed. 
Beard Party
  Charlie Party
  Rose Bush
About the T-Shirts: I'm super excited I will be working with Duluth Screen Printing for the creation of my first-ever run of T-shirts! I will post updates on what the actual T-shirt design will look like as soon as I know. In the meantime, check out their website and feast your eyes on the video that runs in the background. I could watch it on repeat all day.
http://www.duluthscreenprinting.com
Original 8x10 Watercolor and Typewriter Text Artwork: Each watercolor artwork will include text printed from an antique Underwood No. 5 typewriter (you see me typing on it in the video!). The text will be derived from Ingeborg von Agassiz song lyrics. No two watercolor artworks will be the same. Here are some prototypes of what this artwork might look like (these images are just to give you an idea - it's going to be a fun surprise to see what you'll get!): 
Watercolor & text prototypes
 Wanna hear more right now? 
Check out: www.youtube.com/c/ingeborgvonagassiz

campaign.story:
Hi, we're Marateck. Thanks for visiting our Kickstarter.
Marateck is an instrumental rock band that deals in opposites and contradictions: minimalist vs. maximalist, consonance vs. dissonance, mechanistic vs. humanistic. The result is intense, emotional music played with obsessive, virtuosic precision.
"New York-based math-minimalist quartet channels more than any reasonable listener can handle, but in the most efficient way possible. On a self-titled EP released this summer, Marateck's stripped-down, articulate take on math-rock yields a sense of pointillistic perfection. They're adept at both creating a feeling of space and filling it up, shifting between atmospheric passages and bursts of brutal upheaval." - Emili Earhart, Tone Madison
The band is named after guitarist Jesse Kranzler's great-grandfather, Jacob Marateck, who was sentenced to death four times. In his life, Jacob stirred the pot and created dissonance in times of consonance and sought to create consonance in times of dissonance. 
About Time Is Over:
Time Is Over is the result of over 2 years of writing, rewriting, rehearsing, and honing in on our sound as a band. It was commissioned, in part, by Roulette Intermedium and the Jerome Fund for New Music. This is our first cohesive statement as a band, but it is also a summary of everything this band has done up until this point.
The album was co-composed by guitarists Jesse Kranzler & Brendon Randall-Myers and features additional arrangements from bassist Tristan Kasten-Krause and drummer Mark Utley. The album includes the four songs from our trio EP reworked and re-imagined in a grander quartet setting plus four new songs that show where the band is moving.
The album was recorded, mixed and mastered by Colin Marston (Gorguts, Krallice, Behold The Arctopus) at Menegroth: The Thousand Caves and features synth and keyboard performances from Jeremy Malvin (aka Chrome Sparks.) Album art and design will be done by John Robert Moore.
Now that's a Big Gibby if I've ever seen one
Where You Come In:
We recorded the album in the Summer of 2016, but need your help to put finishing touches on the album, the artwork, and manufacture a physical product for you to hang on your shelf.
Where Your Money Will Go
We've put together a set of juicy rewards that we hope will whet your appetite and put you in the giving mood. If you don't have the means to donate but would like to support, please share this project with friends or family who might be interested. We want to get this album in as many people's hands as possible.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
If we cannot fund this project, this album may not see the light of day. We are a fairly young band and do not have the means or the fan base to put this album out on our own yet. This music represents a very specific time and place for this band, so it is very important that we release the music in a timely manner.

We feel confident that, if funded, we will be able to release the album in time for a US tour in July. However, delays with our production plant and other elements outside of our control may impact our delivery date by a few weeks.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
Thanks for visiting my Kickstarter page! I’m raising funds to support the recording and distribution of my new EP, “Way of Dreams.” This album will feature original music for drums, bass, guitar, and two saxophones. This music aims to give voice to the many parts of the self as illuminated through a creative process. As such there will be loud, scary parts, there will be quiet, introspective parts, and there will be plenty of other things in between. I’m excited to share this music with you - but to see this project through, I need your help.
Since childhood I’ve had a deep love for music, and in recent years I’ve been inspired to write and produce my own. Being closely involved with friends on their original music has played a large role in that interest, and watching them put all the parts together has given me examples of how to complete a project. Another influence has always been the deep history of creative music that’s come from Detroit. I feel fortunate to have grown up in such an inspiring culture of artists dedicated to creating and collaborating. As I prepare to relocate to New York City in the fall, making this album feels both like the closing of one chapter and the beginning of another, and this music feels like connective tissue between the two. And even though we come from different places, making this music with musicians I met in Michigan felt appropriate: Andrew Bishop (tenor saxophone, bass clarinet), Molly Jones (tenor and soprano saxophones), Ben Rolston (bass), and Kirsten Carey (guitar).
In an essay on dream analysis, Carl Jung wisely wrote, “It is the way of dreams to give us more than we ask." I thought this was a perfect description of the project: it encapsulated the idea of having plenty of material inside of ourselves to work with and develop if only we were to pay attention to it. Writing this music, then, became a way of paying attention to and drawing from the material already inside myself, whether that meant memories from childhood or a current favorite song. This thinking influenced everything from decisions about balancing improvised and composed material to moods of songs (or sections of songs) to titles. In a larger sense, I believe continuing to use this philosophy as a starting point for creating will help to make future projects more personal and - hopefully - relatable.
Each contribution deserves a BIG thank you, and I’m deeply grateful for any amount. My hope is that the rewards I’m offering say that and then some. Thank you for supporting music for today’s and tomorrow’s listeners.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
My biggest challenge with this project will be staying on schedule to have the album in hand by May of 2017. This includes, but is not limited to, raising enough funds to pay for the steps along the way. However, I'm confident that the team of people I'm working with on this project will help me to meet this goal. I will post updates as the release date approaches to keep supporters aware of the progress.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Hellooooooooo!
I'm just checking that everybody has received their rewards. I sent out the last of the packages last week (except for the paintings - those will go out in the next week). If you haven't, send me a message / email/ text / etc. and we'll figure that out.
Thanks! <3

CDs came today! Holding them in my hands and hearing and seeing all the work that went into them is a reminder that every step of the way has been full of learning moments. In as sincere a way as I can express on Facebook: THANK YOU to any and all who played a part in making this happen! It's humbling and wonderful to be wrapping this project up and moving forward with the feeling that I've grown from this.
You can probably expect your rewards this month. I'll be out of town for a month or two starting the second week of June, so they'll be fulfilled by then at the very latest. Thank you for your patience and your help!

Hey everybody,
I want to give you a quick update on where this album is at:
My good friend Jake Shadik spent the last few weeks making and tweaking the artwork and layout and I can't wait for you to see it.
Once that was completed I sent all the stuff to the magical CD-Making Land (it exists somewhere between Narnia and the 5th dimension - GPS gets spotty around there.) They should arrive back by the end of April!

Hey y'all - we made it! There's no way it could've happened without every single contribution. Really, sincerely, thank you.
Mastering will be completed next week and I've gotten started on art work and design for the album. The next 4-8 weeks will mean finishing the layout for CDs and waiting for them in the mail, registering the music with ASCAP, putting together and mailing packages, painting pictures, writing thank-you cards, and lots of other stuff!

YES! With just a little under half of my time left, you've all helped me pass the half way point in contributions. This is encouraging and exciting indeed. 
The music is sounding really good with Josef's sonic wisdom sprinkled throughout, and ideas for album design and layout are germinating as I write this. This is the beginning of the home stretch - THANK YOU for your help and let's make this happen!
PLAY

campaign.story:
Variety Show
We have commissioned and performed some fantastic music since forming as a duo in 2013. It's time to record them professionally so that we can share this great music with a wider audience!
Variety Show will feature compositions by Drew Baker, Brooks Frederickson, Brendon Randall-Myers, Ian Dicke, Zack Browning, Andrea Reinkemeyer, and Ned McGowan.
The Drew Baker piece is already recorded and mixed. We will be recording the rest of the compositions this month at Fantasy Studios, in Berkeley, CA. We plan to release the album in CD and digital download formats in early October 2016 on the Aerocade Music label.
Your contributions will go towards studio rental, paying for mechanical licenses, manufacturing CDs and publicity for the album.

Meerenai's drawing that will be used on the new t-shirts and coasters.

When we perform more informal shows, we often wear matching baseball jersey style shirts. You can see the back of Chris's shirt below. You can see the front of the shirts in our video above. The personalized A/B Duo Jersey will have your name and the number of your choosing on the back, just like ours!

 Original Artwork (new!)
Meerenai just finished her piece Blueprint for the Soudwave Biennial. It's a graphic score for soprano sax, flute, contrabass flute, and contraforte. You can get the ORIGINAL 14"x11" hand-drawn first panel in a frame! Read more about Blueprint here.

campaign.story:
A Community-Driven Beer Garden in Downtown Waterloo...
Thank you for stopping by to look at our Kickstarter campaign! Very simply put, we at Hopskeller Brewing Company want to engage our fans and community in the creation of a beer garden for our new brewpub in downtown Waterloo, Illinois. Our 7-bbl brewery, which is slated to open early this spring, will be situated in a historic home on the courthouse square and has a sizable backyard that's just begging for landscaping. We've gotten to the point where we can start thinking about how our outdoor area will look; with your help, this will become a beautiful fixture of downtown Waterloo, built by our fans and for our fans!
Our Background...
While Hopskeller Brewing Company may have started out as the flight of fancy of Matt Schweizer, that dream came closer than ever to becoming a reality at Monroe County's annual "Taste of the Region" festival in February of 2014. Matt, at that time a 29-year old history teacher and a homebrewer with 7 years of experience, had presented beers at contests, taught beer history and brewing lessons to enraptured (inebriated?) audiences, and served his beers at more private gatherings and parties than anyone would care to count. Matt's sampling booth at the Taste of the Region seemed to get everyone thinking and, even better, talking: Why can't I buy your beers? You should really look into starting something here in town. We've been dying to get something like that here in Waterloo.
A few hours (and many gallons of beer) later, and before anyone knew it Matt -- along with a group of business and civic leaders put together at the behest of the city of Waterloo -- was drawing up business plans with the Waterloo residents who wanted to see this thing happen... all the while, sharing, sharing, and sharing loads of beer with anyone who could drink.
Before long, Matt and his partners began to attract community members who wanted to volunteer their time and expertise to the project; together with these locals and with well-wishers throughout the Saint Louis area and beyond, Hopskeller is set to become a major staple of the downtown Waterloo experience by the spring of 2016!
The Brews...
Our brewers have won over 15 awards at sanctioned homebrewing competitions across the country since the summer of 2015 alone, so we're confident that you'll leave our new brewery feeling like your donation was worth it! 
Creating and evaluating our Blonde Ale at the "pilot plant"
Our specialties are English-style ales and Northwest Coast American ales. The choice of beers has some sentimental importance; Matt has lived in northern England and Oregon, and both places were instrumental in helping develop his style and brewing philosophy. Many of Hopskeller's beers come from recipes that Matt created to relive the greatest moments of traveling in Europe and the American Northwest, and we hope that these beers will create memories for you, too! 
Matt and our partners at Alpha Brewing Operations (Lincoln, NE) designing the 7-bbl brewery
We will, of course, offer a wide array of seasonal ales and lagers that test the artistry of our brewing team and will hopefully intrigue even the most experienced beer nerd!
The Money...
Take it in, folks: the rest of this yard will be your beer garden!
Let's get down to the nitty-gritty; you want to know what your money will help build, and we're more than happy to tell you. We are well into the process of construction and we're set to open in the spring of this year. Your donation will largely go to providing a community-driven beer garden worthy of its name. Be on the lookout if we go over our target; we can't wait to show you specifically how your money will make Hopskeller a truly unique place!
Thank you for looking at our campaign, and we want to especially thank everyone who donates. With your help, we'll leave a permanent mark on Waterloo that all of us can be proud of!
How to Follow Us...
While we've been featured in local media outlets and publications, follow our story from the beginning -- and stay up-to-date on all of our new projects -- by following us on Facebook, Instagram, or Twitter. We can't wait to hear your thoughts!
----------------------------------------
Music from video courtesy of Gillicuddy. "That Old Harpoon," "Traveling Made-Up Continents," and "Instrumental #2 Revisited" are all licensed under the Creative Commons Agreement and can be found here.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Starting any business is a risky venture, there's no doubt about it. With us being well past the planning phase and into construction, Hopskeller doesn't run the risk of never opening. Our award-winning beers largely speak for themselves, and the level of community backing from our great city of Waterloo, the local business and civic leaders who have invested their time and money into bringing a brewery to Monroe County, and the enthusiasm we've generated from festivals and tastings will all combine to help us overcome the inevitable challenges of starting a business.

This Kickstarter campaign is a chance for our larger community to invest in their brewery -- we hope that the beer garden will become a place all of our fans can come to and proudly recount to their friends how they were a part of its construction!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
I wanted to take a minute to thank all of you for your generous pledges to our beer garden -- together, we did it!! 
In the next day or so, I will have written everyone a short message that thanks you for being a part of this campaign and to ask some logistical questions for your award(s). Please read over the message and respond to me whenever is convenient.

One more day, Hopskeller fans! We've been getting loads of pledges over the past day and still have time to make this happen. Let's keep up the great work, and thanks again for everything you've done so far for us!
  -- Matt

Okay everyone, we have 4 and a smidge days left to meet our goal! First thing's first: thanks *so much* to everyone who has already pledged to this project. Regardless of whether we meet our goal or not, it means the world to me to see so much support from family, friends, and other well-wishers -- some of whom I don't even know personally! That is a very cool feeling, to put it lightly.
If you or anyone you know is considering pledging, the next few days would be a good time to confirm that with us. In addition, if you head up an organization or a business that's looking for a way to be recognized, please feel free to pledge on behalf of that organization. We're more than willing to work with you on that.
