campaign.story:
Gutbucket is releasing its first album in five years this winter 2016 and we need your help in the final stages to bring it to the world...and if you pre-order the album, and consider some rewards with additional gifts, you'll receive the music a full month before it hits the streets, and just in time for the tail end of Hannukah, Christmas, or other December holidays when people give each other stuff. 

Here's the story: Gutbucket spent a week in late November 2014 in residence at John Zorn's heralded downtown space the Stone. We worked with an excellent engineer to turn the Stone into a pristine, pop-up recording studio. So in addition to collaborating with many friends and premiering new projects, the band recorded a set of our newest quartet music each night. We began touring with this music in February 2014, so it was road-tested, well-rehearsed - and is some of our most challenging and ferocious music to date. It's also our first recording with bassist Pat Swoboda, who joined the band in late 2012. We're really excited about the music and bringing it to the world.

For numerous reasons, we've decided to release this one on our own imprint, Gut Records, which is the in-house label that started it all for us back in 2001 with our debut, InsomniacsDream. As you probably know, the record industry has changed dramatically since 2001, so a self-release these days is much more common, but it also requires that we pay for our sound engineer, the mixing, mastering, manufacturing, design, artwork, publicity, and all of that stuff which brings CDs or even digital downloads to good people like you who still like to buy things from musicians, because you believe in supporting their work. 

So we're asking for your help in the final stages of production, publicity and tour support. Plus, we're doing something really fun with this - a first for us - we're making a music video! Wow, hello 1980's. We've enlisted our pal, the multitalented composer and video artist Florent Ghys (www.florentghys.com) to make a video for "Luton" the first tune on "Dance." It'll involve some choreography, some improvisation, and we expect it to be a thing of beauty. 

We're really excited about this project and bringing this music to you! We hope to see you in your hometown during our 2016 tours, and in the meantime, we hope you can help support us and be a part of "Dance."
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Putting a CD and digital download package out isn't the DIY band merchandising endeavor it once was - it's hard to break even when you release a CD. We've worked with a handful of labels in the past, but doing this one on our own label made the most sense. We were smart shoppers when we set up our recording project at the Stone, but we also hired an engineer with excellent gear and wonderful ears, and that costs money. After making the record sound its best, we hoped that by releasing the CD ourselves and keeping our other productions cost sensible, we can funnel all of our money back into covering our expenses. We decided to print eco-wallets instead of jewel case CDs so that shipping is less expensive and the materials that go into the actual physical product have a gentler carbon footprint. 

We also recognize that spending money on publicity is risky - we plan to tour the US and Europe as we've always done to have the most direct interaction with our fans and support our efforts to bring "Dance" to lots of people, but touring is challenging, and it can be expensive and financially risky. We've been doing this for more than fifteen years, so we plan to use what we've learned in order to hit the road in the smartest possible way.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
DEC 10: MST3K's Next Big ... CAMEOS!
DEC 9: MST3K's Next Big ... ARTISTS!
DEC 9: MST3K's Next Big ... WRITERS!
DEC 9: WE'RE AT $4.4MM = 9 NEW EPISODES
DEC 8: MST3K MIMOBOTS® & REWARD UPGRADES
DEC 7: FINAL COUNTDOWN WEEK & TELETHON
DEC 6: MORE ABOUT THE NEW EPISODES
       • What will the new episodes look like?       
       • Will the new episodes be in HD? (And why does it matter?)
       • What kinds of movies will the new episodes riff on?
DEC 4: ADD-ON REWARDS & EXCLUSIVES
DEC 2: WE'RE AT $3.3MM = 6 NEW EPISODES!
NOV 30: PATTON OSWALT JOINS MST3K
NOV 28: SECOND BIGGEST FILM KICKSTARTER EVER!
NOV 23: THE NEXT MAD, CROW & SERVO
NOV 18: THE OFFICIAL CAMPAIGN POSTER
NOV 16: THE NEXT HOST
NOV 12: ANSWERS TO 5 BIG QUESTIONS
     • Exactly how Joel will use the Kickstarter funds..
     • Why the old cast and writers haven't signed on... yet.
     • Why a new cast is so important for the next season!
Hello, People of Earth. 
Welcome! I'm Joel Hodgson. 
Once upon a time, a television series called MYSTERY SCIENCE THEATER 3000 was born. We debuted on Minneapolis' KTMA, local television, on Thanksgiving Day 1988, as the world was in the final throes of Teddy Ruxpin-mania. That was almost thirty years ago, but for some reason, people still seem to like the show – it’s a mitzvah!
Our show has had a long, strange run. Across a UHF channel, a cable network, cancellation, a feature film, then another cable network, the show lasted for 12 years, two generations of hosts and puppeteers, 2 Emmy nominations and a total of 197 episodes before we got canceled again for good in 1999. Sadly, it was just as Prince predicted.
But maybe that's not where it all ends.
Starting today, we finally get a chance to bring back MST3K.
With your help, we can create a new season of MST3K, prove there's still an audience, and maybe even convince a network to bring us back for more.
Great question.
The simplest answer is that there are a lot of cheesy movies left to riff, and a lot of people who would still enjoy watching them with us.
Plus, I think there's a place for us. Nowadays, riffing is everywhere! Many people claim that MST3K created a shift in the way people watch TV shows, and that now, as a result, the fields of entertainment have been plowed and readied for a riffing renaissance.
I mean, look at the influence it’s had... Everyone riffs on Facebook, YouTube and Twitter. Hell, there are ten to twelve people who are still, unironically, riffing on MySpace and Friendster.
In a world where riffing has become as common as our national pastime, baseball, it makes sense: like baseball, everyone knows how to play, but sometimes it feels good to just sit back and watch the original movie riffing team take a whack at it. And if we came back, imagine all the riffs we could make about things like Uber or Cards Against Humanity!
Also, there’s a pile of scriptural evidence in whichever sacred text that you hold dear to prove that we need more seasons of MST3K… so when you share on social media, you know you’re not going to offend anybody.
You know, I just read that last sentence... and actually, I’m pretty sure you’re going to offend everybody. But at least you can rest assured that you’ll offend everyone equally.
We do, and here's why: I think it's because MST3K is more than just movie riffing. It's a stranger and denser recipe than just saying smart aleck things to a forgotten movie, but I think this is the secret ingredient: we believed that it's easiest to survive the cheesy movie that we're living in with friends who keep us from taking it all too seriously.
Now, I don’t want to get too maudlin about it, because being too serious is the enemy of comedy. We weren't trying to send a message: job #1 was always to make a funny show. But while we were doing that, I hope we also helped show the kids that society, and the stupid things we say and do to each other, are "just a show, and you should really just relax.”
Yeah, this is what I was afraid of. Now I’m starting to sound like the Dr. Bronner's label. Next question?
The simplest answer is: until now, we couldn't bring MST3K back.
I've been thinking about ways to re-animate MST3K for over a decade... and over the last 15 years, I've met thousands of you who said that you wanted MST3K back too. But two things have finally changed that make this the right time. And I'm not talking about the legalization of marijuana or the proliferation of water jet pack use.
1. Crowdfunding gives fans the power to get what they want.
In less than two years, I've watched fans use crowdfunding to bring back Veronica Mars, Reading Rainbow and Super Troopers – all cult favorites, like us – and it made me wonder how MSTies would respond if we had the chance to return. Now we're going to find out… and then maybe LeVar Burton can finally stop acting like he’s so much better than us.
2. We had to work through some complicated legal issues.
Even though we've always wanted to bring MST3K back, it wasn't that easy. Thanks to the Last Will and Testament of one eccentric old heiress, the rights were tied up for years. It took time to work those issues out, but with the help of my friends at Shout Factory, a special chokehold I perfected in WuDang that I like to call “The Persuader,” and a night I had to spend in a haunted house as a term of the the old lady’s will, we succeeded.
This summer, we finally got all of the rights cleared up… and now, like Orpheus, we can now descend into hell to hang out with a couple of wisecracking robots.
Now we're talking!
Our Kickstarter campaign has two really important goals.
As soon as we reach our minimum goal of $2,000,000, we'll be able to make three new feature length episodes of Mystery Science Theater 3000. But then, for each additional $1.1 million we raise, we can make three more... up to a full season of 12 episodes!
(If you're wondering why new episodes cost so much – especially the first three – keep going down the page to "HOW WE'LL USE YOUR MONEY," or take a look at the Backer Update where I explained the budget in detail.)
Here's a simple diagram to help you remember our goals:
If we can raise even more than that, I'd love to shoot some (or all) of the new season LIVE in front of an audience – and maybe even stream the show live on the internet! (Oh yeah: I just saw your eyes light up.)
Finally, if we raise $1 BILLION – stay with me on this one – we’re going to adopt a real live teenage boy and “Truman Show” him into believing he is the Pumaman!
Hear us out, because this goal is just as important: we're not just crowdfunding because we need funding. 
We're also doing it because we need the crowd!
If we want a lot more MST3K, we need to work together to prove that there's still an audience out there that wants MST3K – and that this isn't all some pitiable delusion – so that we can find a network or online platform who will agree to pick up the show and keep it going… hopefully for another 200+ episodes.
Even if you can only spare $5 or $10, every extra backer helps us send a message to the networks: it's time to #BringBackMST3K.
____
Okay. It's time for me to put away the grease gun and give you your marching orders.
If any of this rings true to you, we need your help now to spread the word. Back in the day, every episode of MST3K ended with a message that encouraged fans to “Keep Circulating the Tapes.” And you guys did.
Those grassroots efforts helped MST3K find friends and fans at a time when the rest of show business didn’t quite know what to make of us. It was social media in its most primitive form... and because of you, it worked.
Today's, it's time to update that phrase for the internet age. If you're with us, this is your call to action, MSTies.
And while you're at it, you can help out even more by taking a minute to follow us on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram. (Apparently those matter more than Nielsen ratings, now!)
Listen, I know this Kickstarter idea isn’t for everyone. Neither was Mystery Science Theater 3000. But just like MST3K itself, I know the right people will get it.
Thanks for reading. I hope you'll join us. 
Joel
Dear People of the Internet,
Welcome to my first-ever Official Crow-Funding Campaign. Tee Hee!
As #1 Golden Shiny Boy Champion, I need a place to shine bright and inspire. I want to be a part of your life again, serving in both a wind-beneath-your-wings and an ASRM capacity. You know you still want me, baby, but allow me to tell you why.
First, I like POP! Figures. I intend to roll most of the money into Funko stock. Plus a few hat parties.

Also, I’d like to open up a long-overdue public dialogue on Cee-Lo Green and his fashion choices.

Then, I plan on turning at least a thousand dollars’ worth of funds into pennies, which I will press into elongated souvenir coins at theme parks and fairs.

Finally, if you are still undecided, I ask you to consider this: after years of waiting, I will finally get to decide who lives and who dies. You don’t want to be on the wrong list, do you?
I look forward to your loyal service in the many years of the New Golden Age to come.
Your Future Supreme Being,
Crow T. Robot
Hello, Ladies.
I'm pleased to be with you again. It's been too long. Now that we're about to be a huge crowdfunding hit, I've got a few things I'd like to discuss with you.
It turns out that the last 15 years have been kind to our legacy: we're famous now. And not internet famous, either. Real famous. I have lots of female fans.
Angelina, Scarlett, and many women named Madison: I've got parts in the new show with your names on them. You can come over and we can run lines in my bungalow, and I’ll make us a curry. Then if things get “consensual,” so be it.
I’ll also pretty much be the “troubleshooter” on this Kickstarter campaign, because I understand how you think and I’m a master of social media. My god: you do realize that I’m the uncredited creator of both memes and avatars?
I’M ALSO THE FIRST SENTIENT BEING TO TYPE A MESSAGE IN ALL CAPS.
What are you waiting for? Get out to the Kickstarter polls and start voting.
Yours,
Tom Servo
Hey everyone. It's Joel again.
Look, I know what you're wondering, so go ahead… just say it.
Believe me, man. I get it. If it cost $2 million just to make three episodes, we'd be spending almost $700K per show! And you're right: by itself, an episode of MST3K doesn't cost nearly that much. 
The real explanation is pretty simple.
1. We don't get to keep all of the money we raise on Kickstarter! 
CAMPAIGN FEES: Out of the first $2,000,000, we have to pay about 8% – that's $160,000 – in fees to Kickstarter and the credit card processor.

REWARD & SHIPPING COSTS: Then, we have to design, produce, print, sort and ship all of the rewards we're offering in exchange for your pledge. (Those t-shirts aren't free, you know!) That costs about 27%, so that's another $540,000.
(We're not charging you twice for shipping, I promise. Even though Kickstarter asks you to add more for shipping, they count that money toward the total we've raised, even though we still have to spend it on, you know… shipping!)
So, out of the first $2,000,000 we raise, we have to spend $700,000 just on the costs of this Kickstarter campaign!
2. Then, we have to spend a lot on startup costs just to get the show going. 
To shoot new episodes, there's a lot we'll need to do: creating concept art and designs, building sets, making models, creating costumes, adding new features to upgrade the robots, and all sorts of other things. All of that work costs money, which is why our first $2,000,000 includes $550,000 for startup costs. The good part is that every penny of that ends up on screen where you can see it.
3. But... the more episodes we make, the less each episode costs! 
We have to spend the same amount up front, no matter how many episodes we make. If we only make 3 episodes, these costs increase the budget for each episode by $183K… but if we make a full 12, they only increase it by $46K each!
Anyway, once you take out the CAMPAIGN, REWARD and STARTUP COSTS, there's a lot less than $2,000,000 left. In fact, that leaves just $750K for three episodes, which – I hope – sounds a lot more reasonable than $2,000,000!
At the end of the day, our goal is to make each episode for around $250K.
To put that in perspective, that means we're spending less to create 90 minutes of MST3K than even the low-end reality shows spend to make 22 minutes! (Really makes ya think, don't it?) 
Now, if you're as tired of reading as I am of writing, here are some wicked cool graphics that explain all of this:
I know not everyone will want this much explanation, but if I'm asking you to trust me with your money, I think it's important to be crystal clear about how we're using it. 
Plus, $750K for each set of three episodes feels a lot better than $2,000,000. 
(But man, I'd hate to try to sell a car to you people. Tough crowd!)
Hopefully by now, you're already on board. Maybe you're not even reading this. Maybe you've already made your contribution, selected your rewards, and are now rushing around the internet helping spread the good word to all of your MST3K-deprived friends!
But if you're still on the fence, maybe I can make it easier for you.
Personally, I think the most compelling reason to help out is that you want to see new episodes of MST3K… and not just for you. Think of the friends and family who you can finally introduce to the new MST3K: the one with a fresh new cast, fresh new riffs, and zesty new cheesy movies!
On the other hand, let’s not any of us forget: this is Kickstarter. I know that you know that that’s gonna mean some cool rewards for helping us out. And for a show that’s never really been about cool merch...I think we’ve finally got some!
UPDATE! We've gotten a lot of questions asking exactly what's included with each package, so we've put together another helpful little chart:
You can see all of the rewards on the right side of the page, but here are a few highlights:
Become... Part of MYSTERY SCIENCE HISTORY!
All backers – no matter what you pledge – will be invited to join the new MST3K Information Club. (It's like the old MST3K Info Club, only better. And modern. And more exclusive. And wider in the hips.) Over the next year, we'll invite you to help us rediscover MST3K and get it oiled up and running smoothly. You'll be part of the process!
Read... Our Page-Turning Insider Updates 
We don't just want to take your cash and walk away: we want to take your cash and talk away! Most Kickstarter projects promise "exclusive behind-the-scenes updates," but this time, I mean it: I've already started planning things I want to share with you. It'll be like getting email from me, Crow and Servo for at least a year.
Possess... Amazing, Terrifying, Heart-Warming New MST3K Swag
Before the end of the campaign, we'll start sharing the designs we're planning for some of the #BringBackMST3K swag you can get, including the OFFICIAL T-SHIRT ($50+), OFFICIAL MUG ($75+), OFFICIAL KEYCHAIN ($100+), OFFICIAL POSTER ($150), and many more. We've got several amazing artists working on this stuff. I can't wait for you to see it.
Take Control.... of the New Episodes!Bringing back MST3K isn't enough power for you? Great! For real high-rollers, we're offering all sorts of ways to be part of the episodes themselves. You can…
Steal the hearts of millions when you... APPEAR IN AN EPISODE! 
Throw your weight around and… BECOME A PRODUCER! 
Kickstart your new riffing career and… HELP WRITE AN EPISODE!
Immortalize your favorite inside joke with… A PERSONAL RIFF!
Own and Command... Your OWN Robot Friend!
This one is difficult for me, but I want to make sure this Kickstarter succeeds, so I'm willing to make the sacrifice: a very limited number of you can KEEP THE ACTUAL CROW and/or SERVO FEATURED IN A NEW EPISODE! They'll record a personalized video for you, and then we'll ship them off to your doorstep. When we're done shooting.
1. FOLLOW "@MST3K" ON ALL OF OUR SOCIAL CHANNELS.Be sure to follow our official accounts on Twitter, Facebook and Instagram. Ask your fellow MSTies to follow them too! Tell them that those numbers have a really big impact when we start asking networks to #BringBackMST3K for more new seasons.
2. CIRCULATE THE MESSAGES AT THE END OF EACH UPDATE. At the end of each Backer Update, Crow or Servo will share a message or image that you can copy and paste to share with your friends, to help spread the word.
3. KEEP CIRCULATING THE FACTS… NICELY! I know there are still some fans out there who are skeptical about this Kickstarter, about why MST3K costs so much money and how we'll spend it, about bringing in a third cast, about who is and isn't going to be involved… So, like they say on the subway, "If you see something, say something!" If you hear fans insisting that $2MM is more than we need to make three episodes, or that the old team isn't invited back, I hope you'll share the facts with them. (Please be nice, though! The internet needs a lot more of that.)
4. JOIN (OR START) A LOCAL MST3K MEETUP GROUP.
The internet is great, but sometimes riffing is even better when you can meet old (and new) friends in person! There are already a lot of MST3K groups on meetup.com, but if there's not one near you, start one now and invite your friends! We've got some events planned for this month, and we'll be calling on all the local groups to be part of them.
As long as we have the funds we need, we'll be able to produce new episodes. That part is easy! But over the last month, I've had lots of time to think about all the possible risks and challenges MST3K could face...
MAYBE THE WORLD HAS CHANGED!
MST3K has been away for a long time. YouTube didn't even exist when we shot the last episode of MST3K. (Yes, Virginia, there was a world before YouTube. People laughed more back then. Colors were brighter. There were concerts in the park.)
I've imagined many hypothetical risks:
What if no one enjoys watching B-movies anymore? 
 What if you don't want us talking while you do? 
 What if there is an unknown virus that has killed mankind's ability to enjoy a good solid ironic viewing? 
What if kids playing in “Garry’s Mod” on Twitch have made the whole thing meaningless? 
What if robot-shaped puppets don’t have the overwhelming cultural significance they once did? 
What if our collective consciousness can’t take the excitement, and the entire world becomes a flash mob, and we all steal our own TVs?
What if all eight billion people on the planet become a single “Improv Everywhere” troupe, but don’t have anyone left to surprise?!?
As you can see, this whole endeavor is fraught with risks.

campaign.story:
Magic Mountain is the first recording from the Kalmanovitch Maneri Duo. We recorded this album at our favorite hall in the United States: New England Conservatory's landmark Jordan Hall. Now, we're raising funds to release this album and build a new platform for our music and our message.
About Our Duo
The first time we played together, a decade ago, we knew something special was in the air. Part of it is our 'string story'. We both play the viola, the unsung hero of the string world, and each of us charted our own path as improvisers at a time when 'jazz viola' was still an oxymoron. 

Then: Mat at NEC and Tanya in her Juilliard dorm room, circa 1988.
But really, it’s because we share the same basic beliefs about music. For each of us, improvisation is not about letting go — it's about digging in. It's a discipline; a ritual space that binds us to the moment and trains us to be be present to every possibility. When we play, we listen with more than just our ears: we listen with all the parts of our experience. 

We play out of our belief that every one of us has a personal voice—a secret melody—that sings the essential quality of the self. That voice treats tension, uncertainty and difference as literal and figurative counterpoint. It's empathy made audible. And whenever we play this way, we create a space for others to do the same.

Now: Mat and Tanya after a masterclass in North Carolina, and outside NEC (2015)
About Magic Mountain

Magic Mountain is a suite of nine pieces. We started with a simple set-up: two violas, two chairs, and a few microphones. And what unfolded from that was everything.

We borrowed our album’s name from Der Zauberberg (The Magic Mountain), the 1924 book by Thomas Mann. On the surface, Mann's story is about a young man whose three-week visit to a Swiss sanitarium mysteriously turns into seven years. Dig deeper, though, and the story is an exploration of the nature of time: its illusions and distortions, and the ambiguous quality of memory. 

Some people say The Magic Mountain is a challenging read. Maybe it’s because Mann doesn’t serve up narrative in a straightforward fashion. He narrates time the way his hero experiences it: unraveling, expanding, and merging into the present. 

Some people say that our music is a challenging listen. If it's so, then perhaps it's because we don’t serve up our musical stories in a straightforward fashion, either. Are we improvising, or composing on the spot? Are we playing chamber music or jazz? 

As string players, we came of age in a time that asked us to choose between the musical languages we loved. Today, we play music the way we experience, and not how it's categorized. To us, Milton Babbitt is as essential as the Blues, and a Johnny Hodges tone can be played with a Morton Feldman touch.

Much of what we do blurs the lines around musical things. Tonality? From one note to the next, we might find six microtones to play. Self and other? It can be hard at times—even for us—to tell our voices apart. Time? At any moment, we might feel three meters at play. Sound and silence? To us, the music lives in both. With each performance, we create new chamber music that will never be heard before and will never be heard again.

We play what we love

Magic Mountain is full of our personal and musical histories. The track titles form a second narrative, rich with clues to who we are and where we've been. Some of the track titles are borrowed from Der Zauberberg, and others allude to figures whose voices speak to us: pianist Paul Bley, actor Paul Muni, the fictional composer Adrian Leverkühn, and Mat's father, Joe Maneri.

The Dance of Death, the album's third track, shows the connection we feel between Bach's solo instrumental works and Eliot Carter's first String Quartet. We hear an off-kilter swing in both composers' works. Their downbeats aren't landings, but lifts. Their sense of metric weight is dynamic and kinetic. Our opening notes are a gesture that reveals music already in motion. 

Foreword, the album's opening track, is a concise summary of our approach to music-making. Earlier this year, Mat transcribed this piece. (A concert score is one of our perks - see the sidebar.) It was a labour of love that allowed him to examine a compositional process that unfolds outside of the sphere of thoughts and words. 


The album's opening track is a concise illustration of a compositional process that unfolds outside the sphere of thought or words. In music theory terms, it's a three-part sonata form based on a six-note motif carried through extended harmonic and rhythmic development. In human terms, this track reveals a seamless exchange of roles. Tensions and resolutions shift rapidly between us. Long notes become short ones; loud notes become soft ones; one voice's harmony becomes the other's melody.

The title of the album's last track, Paul Muni's Boat refers to a favorite saying of Mat’s father, the saxophonist/composer Joe Maneri. When Joe wanted to evoke the fine line between stillness and motion, he’d say, “You know, like Paul Muni’s boat.” 

We never found the Paul Muni movie he was referring to, but for us it became shorthand for an improvisation stretching thematic and harmonic development at a glacial pace. The long pauses at 3:06 and 3:17 are silences rich with music. Our coda at 9:10 uses microtonality to breathe subtle expression into Mahleresque harmonies.


How your support will help
We've been fortunate throughout our careers to release recordings on a variety of labels. But this music is so close to us that we wanted to be able to retain its personality by releasing it ourselves.
We intend Magic Mountain to serve a key role in establishing our presence as a new kind of chamber music ensemble. It will help us to tour more, to record more, and to catalyze new partnerships with presenters, educators, and audiences in every direction.
Our album is mixed and ready to go. Your pledges will help pay for photography, mastering, graphic design, manufacturing CDs and limited-edition double LPs, and the setup costs to distribute the album through our website. 
Releasing this record helps us to tell our story, and to invite everyone into our conversation. We hope you'll join us.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
In a time of virtual experience, you might wonder why we'd bother releasing a physical recording. Our simple answer: we still believe in the power of objects. 

We love books. We love paintings and photographic prints. We love holding records in our hands, because a record explodes time and space. Our record is an invitation. A single day in Jordan Hall magically expands; the day becomes longer and the walls of the hall grow wider, so that everyone can enter in.

As with any Kickstarter campaign, it's an all or nothing deal. If we don't reach our target, we won't receive any funds. But we're confident that we'll meet our goal, and that the albums and other rewards will be in your hands by May 2016.

Thank you.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Dear Backers,
It's Tanya here, writing from New York with an update on "Magic Mountain". Thanks once again to all of you for helping us to bring this music out into the physical world.
The Magic Mountain CDs are here, and they're beautiful, and they're making their way to you! Everyone who ordered a CD should be receiving theirs within the next 1-2 weeks. If you haven't received your package by mid-July, please let me know and I'll track the package.

The Duo by Mat Maneri
The duo is my favorite instrumentation. To me, it’s the most challenging and rewarding of all. 
Trios and quartets lead us into conventional patterns. Even when musicians manage to break them, the nature of the instrumentation leads the ear to certain conclusions. Instruments assume roles: the leader, the follower, the mediator. The duo breaks these roles wide open: with no one else to turn to, two instruments exchange roles without giving up their own stories.

Hey everybody,
It's Mat here. I had a beautiful night in Boston last night, finishing up my US tour with Lucian Ban, and some old business -- my senior recital at New England Conservatory. My journey at NEC began around 1985. There's been some detours along the way, but two years ago I returned to my studies at NEC. Last night, I did my senior recital with some of my favorite people: Joe Morris, Lucian Ban, Tanya Kalmanovitch, Zoe Christiansen, and my mom, .

Recently, we began a series of essays exploring music and the intangible forces inside it. Mat wrote the first one, describing the moment before the music begins. Here's our next edition: Tanya, reflecting on what it means to listen.
To Listen by Tanya Kalmanovitch
When we listen, we can listen with all the parts of our experience.

campaign.story:
The Project
“…it's the way we process memories…certain memories that repeat over and over, seemingly insignificant, but…they define us. Imagine sharing those personal memories, and reflecting on the deeply rooted emotions that are attached…”
Rushing Past Willow is the culmination of introspection, research, improvisation, and composition. It is a project that will result in my debut album, which will comprise original compositions that reflect on cultural values and stem from authentic and compassionate experiences, repetitive thought patterns, and meditation.
I have performed some of these compositions on programs over the past few years, and there has been an overwhelming amount of support! This has conjured the courage to ask for help with the one essential resource that I cannot provide on my own: funding. Every contribution counts, and I wish I could convey more of my awesome gratitude for your help!
Your financial contribution will help: 
complete the recording, mixing, mastering, and distribution process
fund collaborative opportunities with diverse and talented artists 
create repertoire to share with the musical community
create the CD release event
I aim to release the album by March 2016
The Music
“…sounds radiate from the instrument in all directions, and each one is unique. Your individual experiences further dictate a unique paradigm. Ask yourself, if you captured those individual paradigms, what kind of beautiful product could you create by mixing them together? We’re attempting to combine and enhance individual paradigms for a greater product.”

The saxophone is simply a tool for musical communication. With any instrumental performance, the emotion invested and the resulting ideas that are communicated transcend the instrument itself. On this album, the diverse sounds of the saxophone will be recorded using an array of 13 microphones. Composer and sound artist Jason Charney will then mix these sounds artistically, creating a composite acoustic image of the solo saxophone's diverse sound.
Already, eight tracks have been recorded in conjunction with Bowling Green State University’s recording studio, with four more pieces ready to be recorded. All of these compositions are inspired by friends, family, deep love, crippling heartbreak, numbing recovery, experience, learning, cherished memories; all experienced in the modern world of discovery, chaos, and advancement.
The works included on this album were composed through the saxophone, channeling deep, heartfelt connections in audiences, with hopes of inspiring introspection and compassion. These visceral pieces have grown with me over many years, and they are ready to share. You can help share these pieces with the world. 
Collaboration
“It's an age of connectivity, and collaboration is crucial.”

Rushing Past Willow extends past the recording of an album. In fact, it is just the beginning of a much larger project. Cross-disciplinary collaboration is the next step, and its already happening. By combining these compositions with the endeavors of other talented artist. With your help, we’ll create a product far greater than our individual pursuits. Imagine how much more this project can grow! 
Here's a list of the collaborations already in motion:
A dance film by cinematographer Cody Laplant, featuring the movement of Mauriah Kraker.
A 3D animation  by composer and animator Josh Simmons.
In collaboration with Jason Charney, we modified Erwin Redl's 25-foot-LED installation, “Benchmark,” creating a responsive sound installation that responds to the live performance of compositions featured on this album. Additional film of the project will be captured and produced by videographer and pianist Michiko Saiki. 
Visual artist Tim Zoulek will be creating the album artwork for the project. Digital documentation of the work will then be carried out by photographer and graphic designer Andrew Von Haden.
Sharing the Music
“finding ways to share our innermost emotions and inspiring compassion…”
Notation of these works is underway; attempting to capture the improvisatory spirit of the pieces and affect the meditative thought process that inspired them. The goal is to share these works, giving others a chance to perform the pieces and express themselves.
Traditions
“…presenting views and values of our culture; a catalyst of thought and emotion, employing saxophone sound to communicate in a universal language.” 
These pieces exhibit repetitive, spectral, and minimalistic qualities. They reflect on the views and values of our culture, including network connectivity and advances in science. At their core, however, they are meditations on some of my most sincere memories that spin with the gamut of my deepest, heartfelt emotions.
The vocabulary in these pieces stems from the idiomatic use of the saxophone, and uses sound that has resonated with me for over a decade. The compositions elaborate on traditions established by artists including Anthony Braxton, Evan Parker, John Zorn, Mats Gustaffson, Ned Rothenberg, composers such as François Rossé, Christian Lauba, Gérard Grisey, and an array of saxophonists in the contemporary classical tradition.
Recording
The goal is to complete a 12-track album. The experimental recording process has developed over months of research, during which I investigated the placement of the unique microphone array and a methodology for creating a unique sound image. Recording continues to take place at Bowling Green State University recording studios, with engineering by Jason Charney and myself. The editing process will involve the abstraction of the saxophone’s sound, which will be a collaborative process between Jason Charney and I.
Timeline
It is my goal to finish the recording and mixing by November, leaving time for detailed mixing and mastering. I aim to release the CD before March, 2016. I also aim to have at least four of the pieces notated and ready for publication by this time.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Kickstarter is an all-or-nothing model. If we don't meet the funding goal, this project won't be possible.

I am confident in the success of the multiple interdisciplinary collaborations involved in this project. Already, these projects are moving along quite well! These artists are people who I sincerely trust. I couldn't ask for a better team.

The mixing process is already happening, but there could be delays with the mastering and production of the CD. I am hoping to release the CD in February. However, unforeseen issues might arise, delaying the release.

The process of notating the pieces will take the most time. My goal is to have at least four of the pieces notated and ready to be published by the CD release.

updates.update_content:
Enter Branch is going strong, showing that growth from Rushing Past Willow! Check out the campaign video to hear some of the collaborations with Sean Carey (S. Carey, Bon Iver), Nathalie Joachim (Eighth Blackbird, Flutronix), ~nois saxophone quartet, Tontine Ensemble, and many more. 
We're about halfway through the second week of the Enter Branch campaign, and it is certainly coming along well! Your donation can make it a reality. If you haven't already, check out the project at the link below!

We've come so far. 
You made Rushing Past Willow a reality three years ago! It’s something I think about every day, and I can’t express enough gratitude for your support and belief in the project. Since its release in August 2016, RPW went on to reach a larger audience than any of us could have imagined, with reviews in The Wall Street Journal, PopMatters, The Huffington Post, films that screened around the world and across the internet, even winning awards for experimental film. Most importantly, it did what we all hoped it would do. Rushing Past Willow connected people through sincerity, compassion, and love.

updates.update_content:
Hi everyone!


We've finally reached the month of Rushing Past Willow's release, and I couldn't be more excited to finally send your rewards.  You may have noticed that surveys have been sent to your email address.  Please make sure to complete these surveys so that everything can be sent ASAP.

More info will be coming your way via Kickstarter as we approach the release date, so stay tuned!

Best,
Nick

Hello all,
These past few weeks have been filled with exciting news. Most importantly, three more of the tracks have been recorded! This means that there is just one more to go. There has been great progress on the video, notation, and mixing portions of the project, and so far everything is going according to plan.

We did it!
 Rushing Past Willow is fully funded. Just a month ago, I remember sitting in front of a computer, watching the finished video for this Kickstarter. At that point, eight tracks had been recorded, and only a few people knew what this project was all about. 
Now, I'm sitting here (admittedly with a tear or two in my eyes), trying to convey my heartfelt thanks for everyone's support. Thank you all so much.

campaign.story:
WOW!!!!!! THANK YOU, THANK YOU, THANK YOU for helping us blow past our goal with 24 hours left to go! We are thrilled and humbled to see such an incredible outpouring of support. It got us all really excited to introduce a STRETCH GOAL that we have been secretly (or not-so-secretly) hoping to accomplish.
All donations now will go towards the creation of our first professionally filmed MUSIC VIDEO. If we raise $14,000,we can make it happen! 
Help us achieve our new goal! 
--------
INVISIBLE ANATOMY is a composer-performer ensemble that creates multi-sensory, otherworldly performances. We combine an omnivorous stylistic palate with virtuosic physicality, incorporating elements from classical, jazz, experimental rock, performance art and theater. Our inaugural show Body Parts dismembered, manipulated, and reanimated bodies in performance – creating a chattering chorus of woodblock teeth, wearing pop songs as a mask, and placing screaming eyes on floating TV screens. After our 2015 debut concerts in New York City, we were invited to China for three performances, including a featured solo show at the Beijing Modern Music Festival.
Our new show, Dissections, works with a visual and thematic vocabulary that includes dismantling instruments as they’re played and manipulating live video of the group while we perform. We intend to develop a set of six interconnected pieces that function as a single dramatic whole, building the conceptual framework of the show collectively from the ground up with director Dustin Wills and lighting designer Solomon Weisbard.
Invisible Anatomy’s members—Samuel Adams (bass), Ian Gottlieb (cello), Paul Kerekes (keyboards), Brendon Randall-Myers (guitar), Daniel Schlosberg (keyboards), Ben Wallace (percussion), and Fay Wang (voice)—are graduates of the Yale School of Music. Their music has been performed by the Bang on a Can All-Stars, Dover Quartet, guitarist David Tanenbaum, the Cabrillo Festival Orchestra, Musical Theater Southwest, and the Chicago, New World, St. Louis, Shanghai, Shenzhen, and San Francisco Symphonies, and their music has received praise from the New York Times, Wall Street Journal, and San Francisco Chronicle. As performers, they have worked with Dither Quartet, Contemporaneous, the Trans-Siberian Orchestra, The Legend of Zelda Master Quest, Air Traffic Controller, Grand Band, Opera Saratoga, American Lyric Theater, Novus, David Shifrin, and Bernadette Peters.
—
Our second season has two main goals.
1. Creation and dissemination of Dissections
2. Recording and promotion of our first concert, Body Parts 
With your generous support, we will spend two weeks January in intensive rehearsals for Dissections, then perform the show extensively across the United States throughout the winter and spring. Your contributions will also enable us to record Body Parts at Octaven Studios in Yonkers in April, then return to China for a week of performances in May, followed by several June US festival performances. 
2016
Jan 13 - 25 | Dissections rehearsals
Jan 26 | Dissections preview in New Haven, CT
Jan 28 | Dissections premiere in Brooklyn, NY at National Sawdust 
Feb 6 - 9 | Dissections performances in Los Angeles, CA at Pomona College and 2 others TBD 
Mar 21 - 27 | Dissections multi-city tour in Buffalo, Detroit, Cleveland, Chicago, Madison, and Philadelphia (venues to be confirmed) 
Apr | Body Parts studio recording in New York at Octaven Audio with sound engineer Ryan Streber 
May | Dissections performances in China 
— 
Why we need your money 
Invisible Anatomy is both a performing ensemble and an incubator for new work. The revenue generated from performances only covers a small portion of the overall expenses; the rest, including the commissioning of new work, depend on generous support from donors like you. We put on season one with our own funds and many, many hours of thought and labor from our extremely talented and altruistic friends. We want this new show to be more visceral, more theatrical, and more unified, and we’re asking for your trust and support to help us realize our ambitious artistic vision. 
Where your money will go: 
THANK YOU in advance for any support you can give to this project, and remember, money isn’t the only way you can contribute! Helping us to spread the word about the project with everyone you know, in person or via social media is a small way to make a big difference! 
—
Video Credits
Director: Kevin Hourigan | Director of Photography/Editor: Michael Commendatore | Artist: Lauren Chen | Cast: Ian Gottlieb, Paul Kerekes, Brendon Randall-Myers, Daniel Schlosberg, Ben Wallace, and Fay Wang | Special Thanks: Henry Chan
Audio Credits
Live from Invisible Anatomy’s BODY PARTS concert - Part VII: BRAIN | Composer: Fay Wang | Performers: Samuel Adams, Ian Gottlieb, Paul Kerekes, Brendon Randall-Myers, Daniel Schlosberg, Ben Wallace, and Fay Wang | Recorded by ShapeShifter Lab | Edited by Fay Wang
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We are extremely grateful to National Sawdust for including Dissections in their inaugural season. Now that the venue and date of the premiere are confirmed, our primary challenges include promotion and dissemination of the show. To take advantage of our outreach potential, we have set aside a percentage of the budget for a publicist, and we are currently pursuing a few options and will determine which is the best fit. We also have a videographer lined up for the National Sawdust concert, who will help us create exciting media to publicize our future performances. We had an incredible experience performing in China in May and we are finalizing other mini-tours this winter and spring, a more extended tour in China, as well as other festivals early next summer.

A professional studio recording, set to commence in April, is a complex undertaking with the biggest risk being a potential delay in the projected completion date. The editing and mastering process is anticipated to take one month but could be subject to unforeseen conflicts in scheduling, which may impact the delivery date of the CD. We will do our best to adhere to the schedule as detailed above.

Finally, we are totally committed to the future of the ensemble. This group is a project long in the making; we are all good friends who have known each other for a long time and have collaborated frequently over many years. INVISIBLE ANATOMY is our opportunity to be bold and messy and take creative risks with collaborators who are one hundred percent committed to realizing our crazy ideas.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Dear friends,
At long last, we are thrilled to be wrapping up the digital album for Dissections, Invisible Anatomy’s second season show. We are beyond excited to share our debut album with you.
We couldn’t have imagined better collaborators on this project. Over the summer, we recorded instrumental tracks at Oktaven Audio studios with composer and sound wizard Ryan Streber, and have worked over the last months to mix and master the record with our longtime friend and colleague William Gardiner, composer and noted perfectionist. We have also worked closely with our newly appointed Art Director, Henry Chan, to create beautiful album art. Thanks to your generous support, we were able to realize the album exactly as intended.

campaign.story:
!!!WOOHOO WE ARE FUNDED!!! STRETCH GOAL: if we surpass $26,000 I will make an acoustic EP for every backer, no matter the pledge level! the extra investment will go straight into funding tour costs + the team behind releasing the album, making next year's roll-out that much stronger, and hopefully bringing Hiker to a city near you!
Hello, Internet! I’m Anna Vogelzang. In April I made a new record with producer Todd Sickafoose, and it is the best thing I’ve ever done, and I can’t wait to share it with you. I need your help launching this album into the world; the only way I can finish it is with your support! Thank you for being here with me.
I’m a full-time-music-maker. I’ve been writing songs for a long time. I believe in songs. I spend most of my time driving those songs around the country and playing them for good people. I also make albums of those songs! Like these:
In the final months of 2013, I went on a self-imposed writing and recording retreat, and left with a gaggle of new songs. Then in 2014, I wrote 52 songs! I totaled more than 70 songs in those 15 months. (Whoa!)
Fast forward to April of 2015: I traveled to the beautiful hills of Oregon to make a new album with bassist/producer/wizard Todd Sickafoose (Anais Mitchell, Ani DiFranco, Andrew Bird) and percussionist/drummer/multi-instrumentalist Shane Leonard (Field Report). Of those 70 songs, Todd hand-picked twelve that we recorded live as a trio in one week. Together, we created a lush, full landscape - a collection entitled Hiker. 
There are veins running through this album, a cohesiveness that comes from the songs being captured in a live setting, and an intimacy of a trio's performance uncluttered by superfluous players. It is a collection about the animal nature of being a human, the existence of being a human in nature, the search for home. It's about traveling onward and self-sufficiency and love and family and fear and grit. It is without a doubt the best thing I have ever made.
Hiker will have the longest gestation period of any thing I've ever released - some of the songs are from 2013 - far before Driftless, even; working with Todd producing has been in the works since 2012; it will be over a year, maybe even 15 months from when we tracked it all the way to public consumption. It is the longest I have ever let something percolate. I used to spend my babysitting money immediately on Starbucks mochas and as many CD singles as I could afford. Waiting is a very hard process for me.
It's worth it, though. I know that this is the album I've been working towards for the last 10 years. Every mile, every song, every show led to here. This album sounds most like myself, most like the thing I’ve been striving for. It is the project that makes me feel like I am stepping over a threshold. Making this album was the first time I’ve had a producer fully take the reins - a move that allowed the record to flourish beautifully. The whole session felt like an exercise in letting go, in listening for the purest form of the song, in getting out of the song’s way. It was an amazing and transformative process, and I promise it will be worth the wait.
Samples from Hiker:
Bear
Garden
Hiker
I want to take every possible step I can to ensure this record is birthed into the world joyfully and fully, so I’ve decided to return to Kickstarter. I want Hiker to be released to its full potential - heard by as many people as possible, with an excited community around it. That means preparing for the final phase of the project, which is just around the corner - mastering, artwork, manufacturing, publicity, and paying my team.
This is an All or Nothing campaign. If we don't reach the goal by the deadline, no credit cards will be charged, no rewards fulfilled.
As a first wave supporter of this album, you’ll be on the ground floor to hear the songs before anyone else; you’ll also have my deep-hearted gratitude for giving this record a shot. Beyond that, there are many goodies to choose from, including but not limited to:
the BESTIES package is the best bang for your buck: it includes a signed Hiker CD & signed 7” Hiker Vinyl, a mix CD (or digital playlist for the futurists, whichever you prefer) of some of my dear friends and heroes, 4 buttons, a sticker, a THANK YOU polaroid, & a super surprise Hiker-inspired trinket! (what could it be? sunglasses? shoelaces? dirt? crystals? only time will tell!) (I promise it won't be dirt.)
for 12 kind folks, I’ll write a postcard every month in 2016 from wherever I happen to be. I’ve capped this so that I don’t wear myself out, but it is by far my favorite reward - I love writing letters, especially on the road. your first postcard will arrive before your BESTIES package - in January 2016! let’s talk astrology and weight lifting and music and coffee and car repairs, shall we?
I used these studio notes throughout the whole process of making Hiker - arrangement notes, lyric changes, notes about different takes, mixing and editing ideas, coffee stains, and doodles all appear. there is one sheet per song, 12 in total. I will send you the original page of the song of your choice, signed just for you!
A private concert, instrument lesson, songwriting workshop, or coffee date in the privacy of your own home! Not gonna lie, these Concert Window shows are a blast (Oscar made an appearance during the last one) and I would love to create an online experience just for you - and whoever you choose to invite over!
I will happily Vogelzang-ize the song of your choice. Or better yet, we can work out an original song just for you - something from your personal or family history, a song you can use as a gift to woo someone special, or a song based on the topic of your choice, 100% unique. All songs will be at least one instrument & voice, delivered to you as a WAV, Mp3 or on a disc. (These will take longer than the rest of the rewards, and will arrive separately from other packages - most likely in the spring of 2016. I promise to keep you posted.)
due to popular request: the one, the only, THE CHART! you will receive the sharpie-adorned chart I made to track our progress in the studio - plus! a cover song of your choice, the patron, and besties packages. I don't want to let it go, but I will, just for you.
The cream of the crop: I will come and play a concert for you and your friends as soon as I can within my touring schedule! I made it to both coasts & the south this year, and am planning to do the same again in 2016. House shows are amazing, and my favorite way to interact with an audience. If you have a specific date or occasion in mind, travel expenses may not be included, depending on my schedule. If I’m already heading your way, even better.
So far, this project has been possible because of my own savings, which covered travel, paying the musicians, feeding the band, studio rentals, instrument rentals, production, and mixing - that totaled a little over 16K.
Now, I’m hoping that you’ll believe in this project as much as I do - and will come on board to get it finished and out into the world. 
As you can see, half of the budget covers the mechanics of finishing the album, and the other half will cover getting it launched into the world with a good shove behind it - hence the largest piece of the pie going towards a killer publicist. I can only bang on so many pots and pans by myself, and the team is just one of the things that will give this album legs.
There are other things I would love to include if we surpass the goal - this budget doesn’t include bringing the band on tour (6K!), hiring a radio agent (6K!), making a music video (5K!), new website design (2K!), making badass merch (2K!), and further expanding my team (6K!). First, I just want to get it into the hands of the people. YOU people. With your help, this record has a fighting chance.
I can’t thank you enough for being here, for believing in songs, & for supporting these songs. I am so proud of this work and I am so lucky to call this calling my job. I am beyond grateful for you, my community of friends and family and cheerleaders. I wouldn’t be here without you, and I can’t wait to share Hiker with you.
love, 
anna.
PS, any questions or suggestions? I’d love to hear from you. shoot me a note anytime at anna(at)theanna.com!
Video by Cerulean Pictures / Story photo by Leslie Rodriguez / Cover photo by David E Jackson
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Even though my previous Kickstarter campaign was almost 5 years ago, I feel like I’ve brought the lessons from that project with me into this one. All of the rewards are feasible given the time allowed, and I’ve made sure that I don’t burn myself out in trying to fulfill them. Scheduling the house shows and one-on-one sessions will probably be the most challenging rewards to fulfill, simply because of logistics. The album is on its way to being done, and I have scheduled enough time for it to be finished and printed before the promised ship date of late February. I vow to keep all backers posted about any logistical challenges that arise.

Asking for such a number is daunting and I don’t take it lightly. If the funds aren’t raised, the album will linger and struggle to be released, probably around the end of 2016 or early 2017 - and most likely without a team behind it. This funding will launch Hiker out in the first half of next year with a team of pros and a community surrounding it.

The most exciting challenge is what next year is going to look like. I plan to tour, to try to get these songs in the hands of as many people as possible, and hope that they reach folks who can help me take steps towards a bigger and brighter future. Everything about this album feels like a moment of arrival, and I can’t wait to get there. & I am so honored that you’re on the road with me.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
hello, my favorite people!
today, Hiker is officially released into the wild. it wouldn't have happened without you. I can't thank you enough. thank you thank you thank you. to infinity, times one million, plus 12. 
you can find Hiker on iTunes, Bandcamp, Spotify, and any other digital space where people listen to music. if you feel like sharing the album, I would be so grateful! and more importantly, if you would be willing to of the album on any of those platforms, that would also be fantastic - reviews actually make quite a difference in search visibility, and I'd love for this album to be the first thing people find when they look for me!

GOOD MORNING! I just woke up to find we are 100% FUNDED! WE DID IT!!!! AAAAH!!! thank y'all so much for helping with this final push. it feels like a hard knot has been carved out of my chest and I can breathe a little easier again, and I am so excited to get this record MADE!
like all the wise men say: can't stop, won't stop. we've got 2 more days to reach $26K, and if we get there, I will make a solo EP for every single backer! which I would love to do, because it sounds super fun & I'd like to sweeten the pot for y'all as a thank you - the extra money will go directly to funding tour expenses and the team helping release the album, making the whole roll-out next year that much stronger, and hopefully bringing Hiker to a city near you!

campaign.story:
We, Ashley Bathgate (cello) and Karl Larson (piano) are hard at work preparing for our upcoming recording of Ken Thomson’s Me Vs. (for solo piano) and restless (for cello and piano). 
With two pieces of approximately 20 minutes in length each, we decided to go a different way with this recording, and plan to release it on vinyl, with one piece on each side of the LP.  In addition, the music will be distributed digitally.  This is a project we have been rehearsing for and preparing for for years, and we are very excited to finally get to this stage where we are ready for everyone to hear it.
About the composer:
Ken Thomson, a longtime staple of New York City’s contemporary music and jazz communities, is widely regarded for his ability to blend a rich variety of influences and styles into his own musical language while maintaining a voice unmistakably his own. Embracing the combination of complexity in harmony, rhythm, and form while adding a punk-rock aesthetic, Thomson stands alone in his unique corner of today’s multifaceted musical world.
About the music:
Me Vs. (2012) and restless (2013-4) are two of Thomson’s most recent and substantial chamber works. Both pieces consist of multiple movements, last approximately 20 minutes, and are substantial additions to the solo piano and cello/piano duo traditions. While the form and instrumentation of Me Vs. and restless are a clear nod to traditional idioms, Thomson’s signature blend of jazz, punk, and modern art music is still boiling at the surface. These works highlight the composer’s masterful manipulation of tension and energy. In both Me Vs. and restless, the music churns, building in a wave of dissonance and density while never leaving traditional harmony behind. 
Thomson’s music is notoriously difficult, consistently demanding the height of virtuosity from each performer, and neither Me Vs. nor restless are exceptions. Akin to his writing for his jazz groups Slow/Fast and collaborative group Gutbucket, Thomson achieves heightened energy through aggressively dense and blisteringly fast passage work; he uses the entire range of both instruments, pushing the performers to explore new connections between far-flung notes. In a true Lisztian effort, the performers must precisely navigate lengthy passages while maintaining the steady increase of tension and density, pushing the large-scale form to dramatic climaxes.
About the performers:
Ashley Bathgate and Karl Larson are the ideal performers to record these challenging compositions. Both musicians are widely regarded as expert interpreters of contemporary music. They actively commission and perform new works as soloists and chamber musicians, advocating for composers of contemporary music around the United States and the world. Both performers frequently collaborate with Thomson (both as a composer and performer) and are sensitive to his creative goals.
---------
About the project:
Our expenses for the project total over $10,000 and include renting the recording studio, paying for the recording engineer and mixing engineer, mastering the project to vinyl, vinyl pressing ($3K+ alone), and publicity.  This Kickstarter won't pay for everything, and paying ourselves is not part of the picture -- but we will have enough if successful here to record and press records and get them to you; we will work to find further sources to make sure the world knows about this music.
We are so grateful for your support; this recording will not be possible without your help.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Independently recording and releasing a record has some inherent risks. Without the aid of a record label, the creative and promotional work falls directly on us, the artists. However, while this does present a challenge, it also gives us the freedom to produce a product that is of our highest standards of quality alone.

We have already have already partnered with Paul Coleman, a fantastic recording engineer who has previously worked with Ensemble Signal, Irvine Arditti and many others. The recording dates are set -- we are ready to get off the ground on this project.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Happy July, everyone! The three of us are together once again at MASS MoCA in the Berkshires for three weeks of music and art during the Bang on a Can Summer Festival.
We're happy to report that our recording project has reached it's final step - vinyl pressing. The recording is done, the mixing is done, the mastering is done, and the artwork is done. All we have left to do is to wait for the records to be pressed and we'll be in business. We should have them by late September / early October.
We made it! Thanks so much to everyone who donated and helped spread the word about this project. We couldn't have done it without your support, and we're immensely grateful.

Hi Everyone,
Thanks so much to everyone who has donated so far! Our donor base has expanded quite a bit since our last message, and we appreciate each and every one of you. 
We're currently six days away from our deadline, and we have just under $1,500 left to raise. If you've been waiting for the end to donate, now is the time. If you've already donated, there are still plenty of ways you can help us out. Tell your friends or post on Facebook; help us spread the word! Maybe you might even want to take a peek at those rewards one more time. Did you make a $15 donation for the digital download? Maybe you want to put in another $20 and get your hands on some vinyl!

Dear friends,
Thanks so much to everyone who has donated so far! We are happy to say we've got 19 days left and are just $2,500 shy of our goal. That said, we do only have 18 days left and still have $2500 to go!
We wanted to post this update to ask you to post our project on social media and share it with your friends. We figured if you're a fan of intense piano and cello music, you probably have some friends who share that passion who might like to hear about us (we'd certainly like to hear about them). Also, with Facebook being what it is, we're never sure if our posts are even making it to our friends' and fans' feeds, so the more coverage will be really helpful for us, so people can learn about this project.

campaign.story:
Hello everyone! Thank you for visiting this Kickstarter page. I'm raising funds in support of the release of my debut album. This album will feature my original compositions, and will be released this July. But I need your help to pull it off.
These two clips, featuring Ben Rolston on upright bass and Stephen Boegehold on drums, are a sample of some of the music that will be featured on this recording.
Sympathet:
Parentheses:
-------------------------------
For those of you that know me, you know that music is and has always been a huge part of my life. I started playing piano at the age of 5, and started writing music shortly after that. I've been immersed in it since then, and have never looked back. I honestly don't remember a time in my life where music wasn't at the central core of my identity.
I've been blessed to have incredible mentors and collaborators over the years. In particular, some of the paragons of the Detroit jazz community really set a young me on the path to becoming a professional musician. As a high schooler, I was able to work with Detroit's prize gem, trumpeter Marcus Belgrave -- someone who I work with now as a professional. When I went off to college, I studied with Geri Allen, one of Marcus' students and one of Detroit's most prized exports. Currently, I'm humbled and honored to call myself a member of that community of Detroit musicians -- a community of hard working and talented musical artists who I continue to learn from on a daily basis.
This is the album I've been waiting my whole life to make. This music feels like my native tongue; my home base and natural habitat. All of the work, training, practice, experimentation, failure, and ultimately resilience that has gone into shaping who I am as a musician is manifest in this project. I've finally worked up the courage to share this process with the world, and I want you all to be a part of the experience of making it a reality.
The seeds of this project were planted almost two years ago -- in fact, the earliest composition in this collection dates back to May of 2013. As I've grown and developed over that period of time, so has this music. This particular moment in my life feels like a crossroads between my musical past as a student and my musical future as an artist. As such, this project feels special, brimming with life and potential.
-------------------------------
Thankfully, we've already cleared some major hurdles, which will ensure that this project will become a reality. For starters, all the music is already recorded. Thanks to the incredible talents of Ben Rolston and Stephen Boegehold, this music has come to life in a richer, fuller, and more potent way than I could have ever imagined. Having them as collaborators on this project has been an exciting and fulfilling experience.
Even though the music is already recorded, the process of bringing this project to completion is far from over. I'm raising money to cover post-production expenses. These expenses include mixing and mastering the music, hiring a professional artist (in this case, the incredibly talented Collin McRae Leix) to create album artwork for the physical CD, and printing and duplicating the actual CD's. 
$4000 seems like a lot of money to me, but with lots of people involved, I know we can all make this happen together. Whether you give $1 or $1000, I'm incredibly thankful for your support!
Best,
Michael
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Thankfully, since we've already completed tracking (the process of actually recording the music), many of the risks and challenges of completing this project have already been avoided.

As we move forward, the biggest risk and challenge of this project will be schedule related; the mixing, mastering, and production of artwork will have to happen in a timely manner to ensure that the discs can be printed with enough lead time to have them ready for our July release date.

I'm already in touch with mixing and mastering engineers, as well as the artist, and everyone is aware of the stated timetable. I'm confident that as this project moves forward, we will meet our goal with plenty of time to spare.

campaign.story:
Hi, I'm Nadia Sirota, host of Meet the Composer (MTC) and a violist (Alarm Will Sound, yMusic). We set out to create something really different with MTC — a look into the minds and creative processes of composers making some of the most innovative, strange and breathtakingly beautiful music today. And we wanted to make these audio portraits feel like a musical experience.
Because you supported our Season One Kickstarter, we were able to bring to life our first five hour-long, fully sound-designed episodes. We couldn't have done it without your help. We're so proud of how Season One turned out and so thrilled that MTC spoke to you. 
WHAT YOU DID & SAID.
You listened to Meet the Composer over 200,000 times from over 70 countries, via iTunes, Stitcher, q2music.org, wqxr.org and wnyc.org. Tens of thousands have heard MTC on terrestrial radio in New York (WNYC), Los Angeles and soon Chicago.
We got some great coverage for Season One from Radiolab, BBC, New York Times, Wall Street Journal, and Vogue plus a wealth of social media comments you can check out here. 
Here's what Jad Abumrad of WNYC's Radiolab had to say: "Compelling and beautifully produced. One of the best things I've heard in a long time." :: "Talking about music in a way that's compelling can be hard. And so when people do it well, I just feel like you gotta give them props."
Producer Alex Overington and host Nadia Sirota in the studio.
HERE'S WHERE WE WANT TO GO.
We need your help to raise $20,000 to create our next batch of five episodes about provocative, charismatic, and all-around inspiring composers. Though we're part of the larger Q2 Music family, we have no dedicated budget for Meet the Composer. You'll help cover host and producers' salaries, modest production and promotions needs, and help propel us into another season featuring...
Meredith Monk, Nico Muhly, Kaija Saariaho, Ingram Marshall, Anna Thorvaldsdottir
Meredith Monk :: Living legend Meredith Monk is a composer, vocalist, dancer,choreographer and filmmaker. While all of these descriptors are technically on point, none quite gets to the bones of who she is as an artist. Meredith seamlessly blends these media into arresting performance pieces that feel like rites from another dimension. Through her 50-year career, she has maintained her bright, singular perspective, crafting dozens of surprising, whimsical, profound theatrical works.
Preview a few minutes from our episode on Meredith Monk:
Nico Muhly :: An expert technician, insatiable collaborator and thoroughly joyful musician, Nico Muhly writes for a vivid community of musicians around the world, crafting pieces of all sizes and shapes. Nico’s love of language and syntax finds an analogue in his music, where he delights in cadences' inherent quirks and prods at them until they come out beautifully crooked.
Kaija Saariaho :: An exacting Finnish manipulator of electronic and acoustic sounds, Kaija Saariaho was in the first wave of composers at IRCAM in Paris, working on the bleeding edge of interactive and concrete electronics. Whether writing on the grand scale of an opera or intimate scale of a solo work, Kaija weaves detailed tapestries of sound, honing and re-defining the boundaries of acoustic environments with unexpected textures and color.
Ingram Marshall :: Creator of immersive, expressivist sound worlds, Ingram Marshall’s musical curiosity took him all over the world, from California to Bali, Japan, Sweden and Iceland before he alit, as a pedagogue, back to his homeland in the Northeast US. Ingram superimposes seemingly remembered and misremembered strains with introspective, often electronic landscapes to create music that evokes, nudges and flexes.
Anna Thorvaldsdottir :: Anna Thorvaldsdottir sculpts timbre into large-scale, powerful works. Anna didn’t find composition until she was 19, but once she started writing, she discovered she could not live without it. Taking inspiration from the dangerous, dynamic landscape of her home country, Anna writes bold, toothsome scores with emotionally satisfying forms and sharp, unexpected timbres.
At Meredith Monk's home/studio recording a vocal workshop.
If we blow past our goal we can do even more. We can bring in an additional producer to create five Meet the Composer exclusive bonus tracks of unreleased music—music that can only be recorded and released with your support! We can do more off-site recordings to really bring each story to life; we can even launch a Meet the Composer commissioning fund to bring to life a brand new musical composition, involving you in the process of creation and culminating with a world premiere performance. We can secure the future of Meet the Composer.
LET'S TALK REWARDS!
We have some great gifts lined up this year to thank you. Ringtones of new MTC-exclusive musical pieces from your favorite MTC composers, including Kaija Saariaho, Caroline Shaw, Meredith Monk and John Luther Adams; a Digital Mixtape with music I've recorded live in concert; and our first ever MTC swag: original T-shirts featuring your favorite Season Two composer, plus a limited-edition poster created just for this Kickstarter. 
Choose your favorite composer we'd like to feature in Season Two and wear them proudly! Illustrations by Felix Sockwell. 
Nab a copy of yMusic's "Balance Problems" and Nadia Sirota's "Baroque" signed by Nadia. (New Amsterdam Records)
Receive a high-quality 13” x 17.5” print of this MTC-inspired watercolor of Meredith Monk by Alex Sopp. "Dive into the minds of today's composers!"
Here's a sample ringtone from Ingram Marshall, excerpted as indicated by the composer from his work Fog Tropes:
 And one from Meredith Monk called Eva’s Song:
WHO WE ARE
Nadia Sirota, producer/host and Alexander Overington, producer/sound designer/mixing engineer. Q2 Music staff is managing producer Alex Ambrose and producer Hannis Brown. Video by Kim Nowacki. 
Thanks to New Music USA for their flexibility with the use of the "Meet The Composer" name, which became famous through their legacy organization founded by composer John Duffy.
Q2 Music is WQXR's online music station dedicated to contemporary classical composers, innovative ensembles, and vibrant, live webcasts from New York City's leading new-music venues. Q2 Music, a live 24/7 music stream available at q2music.org, includes immersive festivals, insightful commentary from hosts and composers, full-length album streams, and special live events at The Greene Space at WQXR. Q2 Music is also available via the free WQXR app.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
It can take many weeks of work to complete just a few minutes of Meet the Composer. We edit each interview within an inch of its life; we work on the sound design until it sings. We agonize over every second of each show so it sounds effortless and inevitable. 

We spent over a year grappling with the structure, tone and pacing of Meet the Composer, and though we've found a formula that works, we realize that part of what attracts us and, we think, you as a listener is the sense of play, unpredictability and renewal that we strive to bring to each episode. In a sense, the five initial composers interviews are just the very beginning: we then visit the composers to capture behind-the-scenes moments; we speak with their colleagues and longtime champions for an insider's perspective; we dive behind the words and into the music for what moves us. In this way, each show is completely different, each production schedule reinvented. 

What sustains us though is our love of the music and joy in uncovering the stories behind it, and the hope to share with you how beautiful, awesome and inspiring classical music is and has always been.

Hey Season 2 Supporters!
When we first brought Meet the Composer to life on Kickstarter three years ago, we didn't know what to expect. We knew that we had an idea that we were passionate about and we were determined to make a great show. We were thrilled and humbled to have 293 backers join us along the way before we even had one episode. updates.update_userinfo: Support Season 3 of Meet the Composer
updates.update_content:
Hey Season 2 Backers! 
It’s been just over a year since you helped us bring Meet the Composer Season 2 to life. Your support is what allowed us to explore the sounds and themes of some of today’s most interesting artists. Thanks to you, we were able to build our idea into a compelling reality. With over half a million downloads from over 180 countries . Just a few weeks ago we were astounded to find out that the show was awarded a Peabody (broadcasting’s equivalent to a Pulitzer). It’s hard to believe how far the show has come.

Hey MTC Backers,
We’re writing with great news to share! I am blown away to announce that Meet the Composer has been awarded a Peabody Award in the Radio/Podcast category. It’s an incredible privilege to be recognized by the Peabody committee, which honors excellence in broadcast and digital media. We can’t believe something that was just an idea in our heads a few years ago is now being honored in the same company as This American Life, BBC and NPR.
