campaign.story:
This is Mountain Shark's first album. We have been working together for several years and now we're ready to document our work and share it with you! The recording process is already underway at Backseat Studios in Ann Arbor with the master sound engineer Jim Roll. We are really excited about our progress so far and think that you will enjoy it too! Here are a few roughly mixed samples of tracks that we are currently working on:
Ghost Riders in the Sky
  Chetvorno Horo
 Stolen Child
However, we still have a long way to go. We have a little over half of the instruments and vocals already recorded, but we still need quite a bit more studio time. We're probably looking at about 20 hrs @ $50/hr ($1000 in case you're not into head math) in order to have everything totally wrapped up. Once we have all of the music recorded, we still need to mix and master, which will run another $1000. Then we need to make the physical CDs and cases! We will start with a relatively small batch, so we anticipate only $500 for that. We also need to pay our artists and graphic designers (Kiko Lopes and Carolina Chew) $200 for an amazing album appearance.  $300 will go to fulfilling rewards. All in all we're asking for $3000 in order to complete this project. 
If we exceed this, we have a few different things we'd like to pursue.
$4000- We would put together a tour for the summer of 2016! We'd try to hit our as many of our donors' cities as possible and we'd do a house concert at our #1 donor's house!
$5000- VINYL! You may ask, "Why are you using an outdated technology? Are you hipsters?" No, we are not hipsters... but those old records had one important advantage: they're big! They give you something to hold, look at, and read while you listen. For people who like to sit down and spend a little time listening to music, this is an amazing thing that we don't get to do with digital music. Of course, all albums sold would include a digital download code for anyone who wants to listen that way.
$6000 and above- We will put any extra towards making an animated video for "Stolen Child." The Yeats poem which is set in this song is full of some pretty incredible imagery and we would love to see that come to life. The more money we get, the better the video would be!
The Band:
Dave Haughey- Cello, Irish Bouzouki, Voice 
Jon Taylor- Drums, Tabla
Derek Worthington- Trumpet
Brad Kuykendal- Violin, Mandolin
Production Team:
You!- Financial Backing
Jim Roll- Sound Engineering and Mixing
Kiko Lopes- Art and Graphic Design
Carolina Chew- Art and Graphic Design
Track List (not necessarily in order)
Stolen Child (setting of a Yeats poem) - by Dave Haughey
Vitoria (homage to Dave's wife's hometown in Brazil) - by Dave Haughey
Play Alone (depressing, yet upbeat!) - by Dave Haughey
Leaves Fall Down (song about autumn) - by Dave Haughey
Glorious (an old drinking song)
Ghost Riders (yippe-yi-yo, yippie-yi-yay) - by Stan Jones
Brillig (setting of the poem "Jabberwocky")- by Derek Worthington
Chetvorno Horo (a Bulgarian traditional tune)
Ain't no Grave (a southern spiritual) -by Claude Ely
Stay tuned for updates! I'll be announcing some guest artists and much more!
Thank you for your support!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Our biggest challenges are money and time. We're coming to you in order to overcome the money obstacle. Time is a factor because we are all musicians who have to hustle daily in order to bring in an income. We have to plan weeks or months in advance for our sessions and can often only fit in 4 hrs a week. We need to have this finished by July, so the sooner we finish things up, the better! Once we have the funds, we can schedule weekly sessions for the next few months, and should have everything wrapped up in no time.

updates.update_content:
We're still pluggin' away!
You may have been thinking, "What the heck happened to that band with the shark, and the mountain, and the instruments playing the music?" Well, we're still here, plugging away. As it turns out, an August finish date was a bit optimistic... With a move accross the country, gigs in south america and the middle east, and a whole lot of work to do remotely, I've also fallen behind on my updates. I apologize for keeping you all in the dark!

WE REACHED OUR GOAL! Thanks to everyone who has contributed so far! We been floored by the level of support you all have shown us! We can't wait to continue our work in order to create an amazing product for you all. 
It's not over yet though! We still have two weeks remaining on our campaign and we have set our eyes on some of our stretch goals. with $3400 we're almost halfway to the tour! So let's keep the momentum up and maybe we can get to that vinyl album and animated video!

This was our original kickstarter video! We really got a kick out of it, but we decided to go with something a little more straightforward... hope you enjoy it anyway! OH, and the voices are overdubbed... poorly... they're not supposed to line up with the lips...

campaign.story:
The brainchild of artist Joshua Norton and musician Luke Polipnick, Hideous Monolith is an improvised sci-fi free jazz record that serves as an audio-visual companion to H.P. Lovecraft's Call of Cthulhu. The project is a true collaboration between the visual artist, the musicians, and the engineer. The result is a unique avant-garde interpretation.
Polipnick and Norton conceptually framed the themes they wanted to explore musically, then enlisted three top innovators in jazz and free music: saxophonist Michael Lewis, bassist/cellist Anthony Cox, and drummer JT Bates. Recording/mixing engineer Brett Bullion created additional texture and ambience.
The album takes you through vast expanses of time; from stillness to an awaking period, to the apocalypse and aftermath - Done in the language of creative improvised music and free jazz, with subtle ambient electronic enhancements.
"To us, Cthulhu is the drought in the West; it's the rising, acidifying oceans; Cthulhu is a mutating disease" Norton explains. "These things have been brewing for a long time. Now, the problems are visible and we are confronted with it."

"We love Lovecraft's concepts of expanded, glacial/geological time, and this horrific, utterly indifferent entity that just waits for eons and finally emerges to destroy the planet." Polipnick continues. "The contrasts between these expanses of time and stillness, and the more active, chaotic elements were ideas that we wanted to explore musically and visually".
"This was an opportunity to combine all of our favorite stuff into one project: music, art, sc-i­fi, records." Norton continues: "The intent was not to create a note-­for­-note soundtrack, but more of a audio/­visual exploration of the themes behind the story... A musical and visual interpretation ... a deconstruction."
This project was intended to be experienced as a vinyl record. The music is split into two different sides that cover different musical territory. Mixed especially for the vinyl format, these recordings should be enjoyed this way in order to truly awaken the beast.
PREMIUMS:
LP front cover painting
LP back cover painting
Cthulhu fine art screen print $50
Cthulhu religious icon wheel $75
Celebrate Indifference woodcut print $120
Cthulhu pop out bust $250
Cthulhu pop out print $250

-OUR BUDGET -
$2700: vinyl plating, pressing, jackets, shipping, etc.
$900 mixing
$900 mastering
$1000 studio/recording costs
+ 9% kickstarter/amazon fees
-----
$5,995
www.lukepolipnick.com
www.joshuanorton.net

The music is recorded and mixed, and accompanying artwork is all complete. We simply need to master and print the vinyl. The only foreseeable hiccups would occur on the vinyl production end, which we are conservatively quoting out at 4 months, which should be adequate.

updates.update_userinfo: CD with large format artwork, anyone?
updates.update_content:
Ok, so the vinyl didn't fly. Are we gonna cry about it and scrap the project? Did Hulk Hogan just give up when Andre the Giant has him on the ropes? NO! He dug deep and lifted that poor humungous lunk up over his head and became a goddamn champion. THAT'S (loosely) OUR NEW PLAN, FOLKS.
I'm thinking this:
CD pressing, coming in a kick-ass larger format packaging so you can still be mesmerized by Joshua Norton's cosmic visions. We will be able to cut costs and offer you the product for much less (vinyl is EXPENSIVE). Then you can still buy into all of the upper-tier goodies like the screen prints and religious icons, at a modest discount.

Greetings, backers:
We didn't meet our goal, so none of you will be charged for your contributions. We are looking into several alternatives: a much smaller vinyl pressing run (more expensive) , a cd run, or a straight to digital release. I will post another update in a day or two when Joshua and I have formed a plan.

campaign.story:
OVERVIEW
This fundraiser will cover a part of the commissioning fees and mechanical licenses that I will pay directly to the composers: Gregory C. Brown, Eli Fieldsteel, Douglas Laustsen, Emma O'Halloran, Isaac Schankler, and Tina Tallon. 
Input-Output is my third solo album project. It will include these newly written works:
Pheromone for flute, piano, and electronics (2014) by Isaac Schankler*
Pencilled Wings for flute, piano, and stereo playback (2014) by Emma O'Halloran*
Fractus III: Aerophoneme for flute and quadraphonic electronic sound (2011/2012) by Eli Fieldsteel
New work for flute and electronics (2014) by Douglas Laustsen*
Huge Blank Canvas Neck Tattoo for flute and elecronics (2014) by Gregory C. Brown*
New work for piccolo and live electronics (2014) by Tina Tallon*
*commissioned for this record
Pianist Jacob Abela and I already premiered and recorded the O'Halloran and Schankler in July 2014. Videos of the premieres:
Between February and June 2015, I will perform and record the other 4 pieces.  
I expect to complete the mastering process for Input-Output in June 2015 and release the album in the Fall of 2015.
WHY ADOPT?
"Sponsor a composer" just didn't sound as good. :)
Top (L to R): Emma O'Halloran, Eli Fieldsteel, Tina Tallon. Bottom (L to R): Doug Laustsen, Greg Brown, Isaac Schankler
STRETCH GOAL: If I can get to $4000, I will hire a graphic designer to design the cover art for my album instead of doing it myself. I really want the album to have a beautiful cover that would look good on everyone's 12"x12" posters.
THE REWARDS 
There are MANY rewards and all are unique so please read through them all. 
Listen to and read about my previous albums and the 7" record.
Video of Tina practicing her pancake art! ($25 reward):
Isaac Schankler's Interactive Sound Toy App ($25 reward) prototype:
New $40 rewards: A couple sketches that I took out of one of my sketch books. Not my best work but good enough to share:
Ball-point pen on probably-not-acid-free paper.
Pencil on probably-not-acid-free paper
Please note that the performance materials indicated in some of the $100 rewards are software code or files to be run using specific computer programs. If you are new to electronic music please read on:
All the pieces require that the flute (and piano) be amplified.
You will need a computer to perform all of these works except for Emma O'Halloran's piece. (Although I would recommend using a computer to perform Emma's piece.)
The other pieces use one of these software programs: Max/MSP, SuperCollider, Ableton Live, and Pure Data. 
If you want one of the $100 "Adoption" rewards and have a question about the composition, please feel free to contact me.
If you're a flutist, this is the perfect chance to try performing with electronics! 
Here's an awesome example of one of Greg Brown's Gift Songs ($200 level, but worth $1,000,000.00!!):
Here are the two logos that come with "adopting" Eli Fieldsteel:
Logos by Eli: SuperCollider (L), Eli Fieldsteel (R)
THANK YOU for your support. I cannot do this without your help.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
I've definitely padded my estimates for studio time and budget but the mixing process might take longer than I expect for pieces with very complicated live electronics such as the Fieldsteel, which is a quadraphonic piece. My schedule may slip during the mixing phase if I can't stay on top of it but as this is the fourth recording project that I'm producing, I hope I can make it work on schedule.

campaign.story:
One Group Mind is seeking your help to complete a purchase of a property at 1462 N. Ashland, Chicago, IL 60622, to house our training center, performance space, clubhouse, and offices.  We have already found a location, made an offer that was accepted, passed attorney review, and we are now obtaining financing. This Kickstarter is raising funds to cover the closing costs and part of the redesign of the space.
One Group Mind is an improv comedy organization that offers training and performance opportunities to professional improvisers in Chicago and operates the Titanic Players, which provides free comedy education to collegiate improvisers at five major universities in the Midwest.  Together, the two organizations have existed for 20 years, won awards, and have had alumni continue successful careers on such shows as The Office, Saturday Night Live, Community, Arrested Development, the Jimmy Kimmel Show, and the Mindy Project, to name just a few.
One Group Mind is a membership-based organization attempting to bring improvisers together in order to leverage the size of our community in order to forward our careers.  We negotiate discounts and obtain benefits on behalf of our members in an effort to reduce the costs of studying improvisation.
We focus on team and time for good training.  It is our belief that any team constructed, if given consistency of cast and training, can become a great team.  Only with great teams can we elevate improvisation from a hobby to a professional art.  Our teams are left for up to 4 years with the same original cast at the time of audition.  
We can benefit greatly with your help:
Financial Security.  For 20 years, the Titanic Players and One Group Mind have survived with volunteer financial considerations and contributions of time from its members, friends, and family.  By purchasing and owning our own building, our expenses will be considerably less, allowing us to not only survive, but thrive. With our savings, we can support One Group Mind and The Titanic Players as well as offer additional services like a robust membership discount program, promotional support for our teams, sound and video editing equipment, resources to forward careers, the Titanic Winter Tour, and much, much more.  Once the building has been paid for, estimated at 7 years on our current trajectory, we will one of the first institutions to offer compensation to long form improvisers.
Permanency.  We need a permanent home.  One Group Mind has had to move 7 times in its history, and one event had us closed for 7 years.  The permanency will not only be a boon for our members, who will no longer have to deal with location changes, but also for our marketing efforts, the hallmark of which is consistency of locale.  We will also be able to design the exterior and interior of the space to suit our specific needs.
Artistic Home.  Alongside establishing a home for our own brand of comedy, One Group Mind is planning to expand our slate of performances, presenting shows 7 nights a week while adding sketch (both filmed and theatrical), stand-up, and music to our offerings.  We also plan to engage the neighborhood through participation in philanthropy, street festivals and other community outreach endeavors.
Communal Home. Our planned design of the space has a performance space and rehearsal rooms, but also a self-serve bar and lounge for our guests and a den/hangout space for our members.  It is our hope that this purchase and build out creates an atmosphere of community for those in the immediate neighborhood and for those improvisers and friends who are, or have been, a part of our organization.  
Career Services. Our long term redesign also includes plans to provide a green screen for filming, recording equipment for members podcasts or voiceover reels, a projection screen to show member films and sketches, and a resource center that includes a computer lab.
Alumni Benefits. Since the space will be our own, we plan to use it to trace and record the organization's history from 1994 until today and highlight the members who helped shepherd the organization throughout the years.  The planned space also includes a residential area that could be used to house any visiting alumni traveling through The Windy City (or Titanic Player team!)
Once the property is secured, we will update the Kickstarter with details on location, site plans, pictures, et al.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
In order to make the move, we had to end the lease at our old performance space. Since then, we have been moving from one theater to another, and unable to rehearse. Without finding a permanent home, it will be extremely difficult to continue to support ourselves.

We can afford the monthly payments and we have a gift for the down payment (thank you, Raouf and Salwa Abdelsayed!). However, without your help, we cannot afford the closing costs. Can you help us?

updates.update_userinfo: We got our Performing Arts Venue License!
updates.update_content:
We apologize for how long it has taken to update you!  To be honest, we didn't have a lot of good news to share. 
We received many surprises throughout the process that took our 6 week time frame and turned it into 6 months.  The City's requirements also increased our cost by well over $100,000.  We are still reeling and working diligently to determine a plan to pay for it moving forward.

updates.update_userinfo: We apologize for the delayed update!
updates.update_content:
Apparently, my last update was still in draft mode and was never published, so get ready for two updates at once!
We closed on the property 3 weeks ago. It was a harrowing experience all the way up until the end. We almost lost the deal in the weeks preceding (and almost lost it the day after closing!).
We began the build-out a couple of weeks ago. They demolished everything we didn't need and they put up the framing for the walls that will encompass the bathrooms, tech, and box office.  We designed the space so that for smaller shows that are just beginning, the box office and tech can be run from the same place.  We even added a second row of track lighting as a back up stage lighting so that for last minute shows or stage reads, the tech can be run from the stage!

The city gave us the go ahead at the end of last week!  We are now assembling all of the requirements for the permit application to get the official City Approved Plans.
Our next step is fitting our requirements within the budget.  Unfortunately, we have exceeded the budget given to us by the bank.  We are reducing our scope considerably in order to have the funds needed at closing.  Hopefully, we can bring this back to within reason and close on March 5th!

We're meeting with the City tomorrow to get final approval of the plans.  We had to pull back on the scope of the project to try and get within the budget the bank gave us.  
We are also negotiating with the seller to gain possession of the property at closing rather than waiting 60 days.  So we can start construction sooner and then perform!

updates.update_userinfo: Forgive us, we are being delayed!
updates.update_content:
Thank you for being patient as we progressed through the steps to close the property. We did meet with the City and presented our plan. The City asked us to make some adjustments and our architect is currently completing the mechanical, electrical, and plumbing plans. Hopefully, when all is settled, we will have a layout that can accommodate:
An approximately 50 seat theater with small tables or 65 seat theater with seats in rows

updates.update_userinfo: We're taking this to City Hall!
updates.update_content: We're meeting with the folks over at City Hall today to get our design approved.  Cross your fingers!!!

updates.update_userinfo: Thank you for giving us a wonderful holiday season!
updates.update_content:
We funded!  Thanks to everyone that helped build a cushion for us.  Without it, we wouldn't have made it!  
We are now working with our Architect to finalize our design.  So far, the design has 3 rehearsal rooms, an office, and an Improviser Resource Center, along with a Performance Space that seats at least 50 people (with small backstage rooms) and a small clubhouse where our members can socialize before and after shows.  We're trying to work in a small lobby with some bathrooms and squeeze in a !

We are in that part of the process where we are waiting to see if all of our contributions have cleared.  (a little tense given the recent breaches at retailers and cab companies where new cards were issued).
So, just a reminder to check your junk or spam folders for anything from Kickstarter or Amazon Payments.  If your card expired, they offer this 7 day window from the project closing date to make the correction.  (you would receive an email with a "Fix it" link)

updates.update_userinfo: Thank you, Thank You, THANK YOU!
updates.update_content:
Myself, and everyone at One Group Mind and The Titanic Players, are so overwhelmed by your generosity and the support that you have given us.  We promise we won't take this lightly and we will do our best to make you proud of us!  
UPDATE:  We reached our goal and our campaign ends today at 1:00pm. We are a little worried about expired cards and fake pledges.  (Mainly because Kickstarter put the fear in us :)  )  We have built a decent buffer and we are hoping to reach $22,000 to cover the 10% Kickstarter recommends to be safe.

campaign.story:
“I learned this, at least, by my experiment: that if one advances confidently in the direction of his dreams, and endeavors to live the life which he has imagined, he will meet with a success unexpected in common hours.” ― Henry David Thoreau 
I left Chicago on March 22nd, 2008 with the aspiration of touring indefinitely. I had no idea how long it would last, but I decided it was the thing I loved doing most, and so I would keep touring until I didn't love it anymore, or until I couldn't make it work. Here I am 6 years and 7 months later, and somehow I'm still going. The vehicle I had for the first 5 years or so was a key factor in me making it work for so long. The Jambulance, as it came to be called, was a re-purposed ambulance that ran on veggie oil. In this topsy-turvy world of weirdo music and pass-the-hat gigs, the ONLY way I was able to keep afloat was having a van that (a) didn't require gasoline, (b) was large enough to sleep in when necessary.
Sad to say I had to put that noble steed out to pasture about a year ago, and now I need a new vehicle to continue my Infini-Tour. Here's where you come in (if you're so inclined). My next vehicle will follow in the Jam's footsteps in some ways, and be different in some ways. Like its predecessor, it needs to be something reliable and large enough for me (and my upright bass and other musical equipment) to live out of. And most importantly, it needs to run on vegetable oil. I want to avoid burning petroleum for ecological as well as economical reasons, since a tour of this length would leave an awful carbon footprint if fueled by gasoline, and since this massive a tour would simply not be financially feasible given the wages I tend to make playing house shows, galleries, and whatnot.
Adapted to my intinerant, musical lifestyle, this machine is to be a work of art in itself—a tool in my continued striving to live exactly the life I want, with music and travel at its center. There are things I want to do in the new van that I don't feel I did enough of in my last one. First among these things is I want to educate more folks on vegetable oil as a fuel source. I pledge to do what I can to host workshops and classes on veggie oil collection, filtration, and operation. For that reason, I’ve even made one of the rewards here on Kickstarter focus on doing just that. And more generally, I want to use my travels to make whatever contributions I can to the political struggles I think are important. For the last year or so, I've been involved in creative projects to bring more attention to the need for reproductive rights in the US, releasing a compilation of Kate Bush covers that has benefited clinics and reproductive justice groups around the country. I'm ready to take that project on the road by organizing benefit concerts for the same cause. One great social benefit of us nomadic types is that we can be involved in communities spanning continents, and can sometimes offer perspective on social issues. When Occupy first got off the ground, I spent time at encampments in Washington DC, Berlin, London, and many smaller towns, and was able to tell folks there what things were like at other places I’d visited.
In the year since the Jam met its demise, I’ve continued to tour without a van of my own, and let me tell you, it was rough at times. I toured on buses, trains, planes, ferries, and toured with other folks all I could. The touring with other people was generally pretty great. But as you can imagine, I sorely miss having my own means of transportation and the independence of movement that affords. The greyhounds and megabuses… well, let’s just say I shan’t be doing that again any time soon. But I did this ridiculous stuff because touring is what I love to do, and it’s my life’s adventure. I am undyingly grateful to all those who have helped me continue on this journey for so long, and I’m already indebted to all of the folks who will chose to help in this crowd-funding project. I only hope that it represents some kind of investment for all of you out there—that by helping get me back behind the wheel, you’ll be glad to see me in your town playing music sooner than later.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Buying a used vehicle always carries some risk. I am asking for $5000 to complete this project, knowing full well that the conversion to run on veggie oil will cost at least $2000, and that $3000 might not buy me a van in great condition. I have been scouring Craigslist and asking friends to keep an eye out, but the nature of buying a used vehicle is that I'll have to see what is available when I am ready to buy, and get the best thing I can at that time. Years on the road will help me to be prudent in my choice, regardless of the amount of money I raise here. Obviously, the more I can raise, the more confident I'll be in the vehicle I choose for this project. I trust that with supporters who have already reached out to me from all over the world, I should be able to accomplish this goal, and choose the best vehicle for my needs. 

Another challenge concerns the conversion to veggie oil. It is not a widely used or understood fuel source. I even once had a professional mechanic in Michigan tell me that running a vehicle on vegetable oil was, in fact, "a myth." I could only walk away, telling him I'd been living that myth for a few years now. Fortunately, I have already selected a mechanic that worked on my previous vehicle to do this conversion, and he has always been happy to advise me on any maintenance I should need. I know from the 6 years since he did my first conversion that he is reliable, trust-worthy, and very competent. He will work with me, as he has done already, to make sure I understand the modifications he makes on the vehicle so that I can maintain and use it properly.
 
If I hadn't already been on tour since 2008, I would say that a major challenge of this project would be the lifestyle itself--having only 4 wheels for a home, and usually changing locations every day or two. But having done it for so long, it has become my way of life, and this no longer troubles me in the least.

updates.update_content:
Hey friends. 
I'm pretty overjoyed at the moment.  As you've probably seen already, the campaign was successful, and so hopefully I'll be picking out a new (to me) van soon.
I can't tell you how much I appreciate all the love and support. I've been trying to make my way through the massive list of your, and make sure to communicate this individually, not just through this mass update. I have tonight off, so I've made some headway, but it may take me a bit longer before I'm done.  To all the folks I I need to send something in the mail, can you please send me your address if you haven't already?  I've been requesting it individually, but if you want to send me that, it'll speed up the process of me getting the rewards out.  Thanks a million.  Now off to keep looking at Craigslist vans.

updates.update_userinfo: One week go go! Please tell your friends.
updates.update_content: Hello good people. An hour ago marked exactly one week until the end of my fund-raising campaign to buy a new van. As many of you know, I set the goal fairly low because Kickstarter is all-or-nothing, and I didn't want to risk the possibility of losing it all if I didn't raise enough. As I continue to scour the webernets for decent used vans, I'm not finding much below the $5000 range. To get a van for that much, and still be able to convert it run on veggie oil, and pay the fees that Kickstarter and Amazon take, I really need to raise something closer to $7500.

updates.update_userinfo: Massive amounts of grattitude and a little stress, 1 week into the campaign.
updates.update_content: Hey there friends.  I wanted to give a little update on the crowd-funding campaign, since a number of folks have been asking how it's going. For the most part, it's already been amazing. The fact that anyone at all is helping me realize the continuation of my dream is in itself, incredibly humbling and it embiggens my soul in ways I can't relate. That said, I'm still a little stressed about it. As is probably typical with these sort of things, there was a big surge on the first couple days, but now that it's a week into the campaign, things have tapered off a bit. A number of folks have assured me that they plan to pledge later, and I appreciate that greatly. But probably until the thing is successful, I'm going to stress a wee bit. The thing that's maybe the most stressful is that I low-balled the amount needed, because I didn't think I could confidently raise more than $5000. But I've been searching the craigslist ads for weeks, and there are very few vans in that range. And since I know that having the van converted to run on veggie oil will cost around $2000, that means that if I make $5000, Kickstarter and Amazon take their cut (which will be a little over $400), and then with the $4600 left, I'll only have $2600 to buy a van. The vans that $2600 will buy (from what I'm finding so far) are old buggers with serious issues. So I'm really crossing my fingers that not only will the campaign be successful, but that I'll somehow manage to raise a couple extra thousand dollars to be able to actually buy a van that is roadworthy for $5000 or more and still have money for the conversion. Is that too much to hope for? I honestly don't know, and I fluctuate between extreme optimism and extreme pessimism. But just like my grandma used to say, "Fuck it, let's go bowling." Love you guys. Thanks for all the awesome support. Fingers double-crossed. Thumbs held. Stars and pennies in fountains duly wished upon. Let's do this.

campaign.story:
I'm very excited to introduce you to my new album! This album is my letter of gratitude to the city of Detroit and all of the amazing mentors, family and friends that I have here.
These are all original compositions by myself. Helping me perform this music are some really great Detroit musicians including:
Michael Malis - Piano
Ben Rolston - Bass
Stephen Boegehold - Drums
and our special guest, Kris Johnson - Trumpet
The Marcus Elliot Quartet has been a working ensemble since 2007, but this configuration of musicians have been working together for the past 2 years. We have performed every Tuesday at a great Jazz venue in Detroit called Cliff Bells, where we have formed a very strong group sound. I am very thankful to have such dedicated musicians that are willing to rehearse on a regular basis and work on my compositions, and you will hear this dedication inside of the music recorded for this album.
Kris Johnson is a mentor and a colleague of mine. This man inspired me at a very young age to write music and to form my own group when I was 17. Since then, I have had the true pleasure of playing in his ensembles and sharing the bandstand with him on various other occasions. We have a very strong chemistry musically and this will be made very clear in the recording of this album.
Independently releasing a record is a gratifying experience, however it is also very costly. While I am funding the promotional aspect of the record myself, I've decided to use Kickstarter to help with other expenses, and do a pre-sale of the CD.  However, Kickstarter projects are based on all or nothing funding, meaning that the funds for this project are released only if it reaches the goal of $5000.
The $5000 funding goal will be used for studio expenses, and mass production of the CD's including:
Time in the Recording Studio
Mixing/Mastering
The musicians in the band
Professional artwork for the CD & liner notes
Duplication/Printing
Here's how the donation process works:
Once you click the green pledge button, you'll select a pledge amount and then your payment will be processed through Amazon but you won't be charged until the project is over on October 31st.
I am extremely grateful to have you as a backer for this project. I am also grateful that I will get a chance to give back to a community that has given so much to me. I have spent most of my life studying/writing/performing music and It is very exciting for me to share my music with you. 
If you have any questions regarding the project, please feel free to click the "Ask a question" button below.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
After successfully funding the project, there are other challenges that may arise, including: CD replication, booking shows, and the recording session itself. I am confident that both the band and I will rise to the occasion and provide listeners with a high quality product.

My debut album "A Beautiful Mess" will have 9 tracks when completed, all original works written for a combination of saxophone, effects, and voice. I met the 9 composers writing for it at the Bang on a Can (BOAC) Summer Music Festival at MASS MOCA summer of 2013 where we got to spend 3 weeks together with daily rehearsals, concerts, seminars, and time to create new music together.
The composers are Alex Dowling, Adam Cuthbért, Ben Hjertmann, Brendon Randall-Myers, Emma O'Halloran, Erik Deluca, Finola Merivale, Max Stoffregen, and Stephen Feigenbaum.
The sound engineer I'm working with is a fellow saxophonist and BOAC alum, Zach Herchen. So far we have recorded 3 of the tracks, the works by Alex, Ben, and Emma, and those are the clips you hear in the video.
Your financial support will allow me to get back into the studio with Zach to complete the remaining 6 pieces. It will also help pay the commission fees and allow me to afford the cost of making the CD's and rewards. Any additional support over our goal will go into touring. I want to play their music as many places as possible!
Financial breakdown:
Recording, mixing, mastering: $1,900
Cost of making the CD's- $800
Commission fees- $1,800
Miscellaneous fees and taxes- $500
Total Budget= $5,000
Thank you for reading. I appreciate your support! 
Yours,
Kendra Emery

campaign.story:
Now that I've introduced myself awkwardly over video, allow me the slightly more affluent textual introduction: I'm a guitarist in Ann Arbor, Michigan. The Ulysses Project is my debut album - it's a suite of ten songs that are the product of my obsession with the novel Ulysses by James Joyce. And the best part is that I somehow roped in a ridiculously awesome group of people to play with me and indulge my tangents on (for example) evil racist dogs, how-Stephen-is-depressed-but-really-just-like-you-and-me, masochistic gender swaps, etc.
These amazing personages are none other than: Derek Worthington, trumpet; Patrick Booth, tenor and soprano saxophones; Ben Willis, bass; Jon Taylor, drums; and Kirsten Carey, guitar (that's me!). Featuring: Corey Smith, wordsmith/keyboards and Heidi Madagame, male tenor impersonator extraordinare
(We are releasing one video a week for the duration of the campaign - stay tuned!)
With this collection of songs, I hope to reach a much larger audience than those who normally listen to free jazz, or those who have geeked out over Ulysses, or the even smaller circle of the common ground between those groups. I hope to create an album where the reference work creates a palette of tones, ideas, and (hopefully) emotions that are accessible to everyone. I'm still humbled by remembering the people (who hadn't read Ulysses) that came up to me after the first performance of the suite and said the last song made them cry...
And though I am marketing the album as "free jazz", I rather despise labeling like that, since a lot of stylings of rock, funk, soul, etc. have crept into the music. "Boyaboy" in particular does with music genres what Joyce does with the English language in "Oxen of the Sun": it travels through as comprehensive and long a list of musical styles as one sextet can muster, including monk chants, turn-of-the-century Irish bar songs, metal, bebop, funk, disco, blues... and on and on and on.
The live version of the suite contains text in between songs, to provide context for the proceeding song, as well as to add a dramatic element that makes the live experience different than the album. Here is the track listing, as well as the chapters of the excerpts that accompany them:
(Sirens) Seaside Girls/Who Goes With Fergus
(Proteus) Dedalus
(Lotus Eaters) Imagined Promenade for Mr. Flower
(Wandering Rocks) Shamefaced Peaches
(Circe) Musksweat
(Oxen of the Sun) Boyaboy
(Nausicaa) Gerty’s Lament
(Cyclops) Beware of Garryowen
(Ithaca) Laughinglike (Unconquered Hero)
(Penelope) O
Also check out for more geek-specific explanations and tangents:
www.kirstencareymusic.com/ulysses
www.theulyssesproject.tumblr.com
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
In order to make this ultimate geek-dream a reality, there is unfortunately the Money Factor. I need to cover the costs of booking a recording studio, hiring an engineer, mixing, mastering, distributing (physically and electronically), and paying for artwork. Any contribution makes a difference and is worthy of as many thank-yous as my guitar-stiffened fingers can type/write. $2,800 is a minimum amount: it's likely that some costs will come out of my own studentpocket. And in the event that we raise more than needed, it will fund a tour in the fall of 2013 or winter of 2014 and help us travel to further and more magical horizons than the cozy abodes of the midwest.

updates.update_userinfo: Hey, so isn't this album coming out in two weeks?
updates.update_content:
Answer: YES!
After over two months of bothering my mixer, masterer, and artists to no end with my incredible nitpickiness, the Ulysses Project is, I'm elated to say, about to be released to be pressed! It LOOKS incredible, it SOUNDS incredible, and I'm incredibly confident that none of you will be disappointed!

Hello lovely Kickstarter contributors!
I hope you are all having excellent summers! I thought it was high time that I sent you all an update on the progress of the project, so here goes nothin':
The band and I have (with much debate and some very hard decisions) picked all the primary takes to put on the album. We hope to get one or two alternate takes mixed as goodies that I will send along exclusively to you all. The only track that remains more or less "incomplete" is "Boyaboy," as I decided to piece it together AFTER all the sections have been mixed. But "Boyaboy" and all the other tracks have been carefully packaged and sent along to our lovely and unbelievably-appropriately named mixer Michael Musick. I'm going to meet with Michael in New York City in July to go over the mixes, and will report back!

YEAHHH!!!!!!!!!!
Firstly, my deepest thank yous to each and every one of you. If I could give each of you a hug and a high-five, I would, but alas you are all spread from Idaho to France. (One of you is in Berlin right now. You know who you are - hello there!) Just know that your support in this project meant the world to me.

Hello again!!
Here we are - 58 hours left, and still about $200 to go. It's an exhilarating race to the finish line - and we WILL finish! But remember, Kickstarter is all-or-nothing, and $2800 is a minimum "price tag"! I'm preaching to the choir of course - but if you are so inclined to do some elbow-nudging to potentially interested parties, now's the prime time to nudge!

Hello all you lovely people, and Happy Mother's Day!
Firstly, thank you ALL for your support! I'm in a consistent state of humbled amazement by your generosity. Thank you so much for believing in this suite. We recorded the album a few weeks ago, and it's going to be truly amazing, thanks to all the wonderful musicians that are going on this journey with me.

updates.update_content:

Just a quick note to reiterate my thank yous for supporting this campaign... Really, I can't say "thank you" enough to each and every one of you. Your support means the world to me.
And to keep you convinced that your donation has not been spent for mere foolish shenanigans, here's another video of the group performing another song from the album, "Imaginary Promenade for Mr. Flower." (My homage to Bloom's alter-ego.)

Hello again!
Sorry to spam your inboxes like this, but apparently the Youtube link for Dedalus was incorrect. Here's the REAL video.

Hello all you lovely donorpeople!!
It's an exciting time, make no mistake of that - day two of the album recording is about to unfold. And it's been a mere week and we've already broke a thousand. Thank you ALL for your support - it's really humbling, and I'm so excited to share this suite with all you. It's gonna be da bomb (to put it in the colloquial terms so popular with kids nowadays).

campaign.story:
Dave King Trucking Company is the latest group formed by drummer/composer Dave King, known for his work in the groundbreaking jazz trios The Bad Plus and Happy Apple. Also featuring guitarist Erik Fratzke, bassist Adam Linz and saxophonists Chris Speed and Brandon Wozniak, DKTC turned heads in 2011 with a debut album called Good Old Light (Sunnyside). The group is poised to release a full-length follow-up in Fall 2013, and this Kickstarter project will help make it happen.
The backer rewards outlined here allow you to preorder the album and, if you like, choose additional rewards including music lessons, signed merchandise and other “interactive” experiences. Oh, and a gold tooth. 
Because we believe in the simple idea that a physical LP is way cooler than a bunch of ones and zeros on a hard drive, all album preorders are for the vinyl edition, which will include a download code for digital versions of all album tracks.
About Dave King Trucking Company:
"...dirty, aggressive, disciplined joy..." - New York Times
"... ferociously energized … smart, joyous energy ... " – Jazz Times
"... swirling tonal palettes … a near-psychedelic jazz mutation” – Utne Reader
Listen to tracks from Good Old Light here.
About Dave King:

King for Two Days documentary film
DaveKing.net

campaign.story:
I'm a trumpet player, composer, and improviser living in Ann Arbor, MI.  My focus is on composing and performing creative, experimental jazz.  For over a year, I've been leading the Arbor Composers Collective, a 9 to 10-piece ensemble that workshops and performs original music.  In the spring, we went into the studio and recorded six of my compositions.  I am quite proud of the results, and would love to have a professional product for people to enjoy.  This is where you come in!  Apparently having music recorded is not the only step in putting an album out.  Your generous donations will help fund the audio mastering, album art, and CD production and distribution.  You will also get sweet sweet rewards.
The Arbor Composers Collective is comprised of many of the most talented, creative musicians in the Ann Arbor area.  In addition to myself, the album will feature:
Gabe Steiner, trumpet
Michael Musick, tuba
Will Marriott, soprano saxophone
Molly Jones, alto sax
Patrick Booth, tenor sax
Dave Haughey, cello
Billy Satterwhite, bass
Jon Taylor, drums
With special guest Emily Berman, voice
You can listen to two (unmastered) tracks from the album right here!  (If the audio players aren't working, you can listen at my website.)  The first is called Reasons and Boundaries:
And the second is called Brillig:
For other recordings of my music, and more information about me and other projects I'm involved with, you can visit my website: www.derek-worthington.com.

campaign.story:
Last year we released an album called Time Is Passed, a collection of original holiday and year-round tunes that we recorded at our home studio, The Sewing Shop. 
Initially we created the album as a soundtrack for the film Losing Ferguson which premiered last November. Unexpectedly, we ended up liking the songs so much that we rushed to make them available to the public in time for Christmas. This meant, however, sacrificing any time to promote or do fancy packaging.
Since then, we've had a whole year to listen back, and realized one other thing: we think maybe the record is a little too short. 
This year, we want to re-release the album REMIXED and REMASTERED with MORE SONGS, NEW AND EXTENDED VERSIONS OF SONGS, DELUXE PACKAGING (with MORE ARTWORK), and an MUSIC VIDEO by animation director TRISHA GUM (Robot Chicken).
We've been working around the clock on the new recordings and putting finishing touches on the album and are really proud of what it has finally become. 
Now we need to raise funds in order to do a proper release of this product. 
If you want to contribute to this project, please be aware that we do not just want donations. We want to give you real, tangible, quality artwork in exchange for funds. If you're interested, please check out all the handmade original art pieces we are offering for pledges. Thanks a lot. 
Here are some of the cool rewards:
Choose whichever art you like for the picture on this reward.
Choose your favorite image. Hand-drawn and painted by Laura Weinbach
Choose from a number of cool silhouettes
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The video we plan to make with the money raised from this campaign is going to be a complicated and detailed art project. Luckily we will be working with a highly skilled and experienced professional animation director, Trisha Gum. She has already rounded up a crew of other eager animation film professionals who will be involved in the making of this project and presented us with a thoughtfully fleshed-out concept and story board for the video. Along with a detailed timeline and plan of action for completing the video, we have the utmost confidence that we will succeed in producing the film in a timely manner.

As far as producing and distributing the album and prizes to contributors, we don't feel there is much of a risk involved with that. We have already completed the album and are having the copies pressed now. Though the higher end prizes are elaborate handmade individual works of art which will require time and precision, we have designated a substantial amount of time into our schedules in order to ensure completion and distribution of each item.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
What is this project?
I have long been dreaming of a body of music that sounds both old and new, integrating up the music of my youth with that of my adulthood, rooted in jazz but not bound by it, embracing pulse, harmony, and form, but not limited by them. This music would require special players to execute, and the right situation to bring them together...
My Opportunity
I have been selected by the Madison Music Collective (MMC) to appear on their Fall Jazz Series at the Brink Lounge in Madison, WI on Sunday November 4th. This entails a workshop on improvisation, and a public concert which will be broadcast live on the web and through Madison's WORT FM. The funding for this concert is enabling me to bring together what I have long considered a "dream band," and is a perfect opportunity to compose a set of entirely new music for them. Opportunities like this rarely present themselves to me, so I feel like I would be a FOOL to miss recording this special band in a professional studio.
Time in a pro recording studio is expensive!, and producing a finished product requires working in stages (recording, mixing, mastering). Your contribution will help me to record and mix this record, and you will be taking part in a major milestone in my life as a creative musician. This would be my debut jazz recording involving my compositions, and I am hoping it will raise my profile in the larger jazz and improvised music scene and lead to better opportunities for in the future.
The Budget
Kickstarter goal: $2200                                                                              -Tracking time: $800                                                                                     -Mixing time: $1000                                                                                     -Kickstarter and Amazon fees (10% total): $200                                         -Materials fees for rewards: (Cassettes: $80; Score books: $120)
The Players
MIKE PRIDE (drums/percussion) Based in New York for the past decade, Mike Pride currently leads the quartet, From Bacteria To Boys, who record for AUM Fidelity Records. Pride is renowned worldwide for his ability to excel in a wide range of genres and ensembles. He has worked with everyone from improvised music icon Anthony Braxton to punk legends Millions Of Dead Cops, toured extensively on four continents and appeared on more than 75 recordings. A short list of his collaborators includes Boredoms, Califone, Eugene Chadbourne, Chinese pop-star Priscilla Chan, Nels Cline, Trevor Dunn, Milford Graves, Mary Halvorson, Curtis Hasselbring, Jon Irabagon, Haino Keiji’s Fushitsusha, George Lewis, Bill McHenry, Tony Malaby, Ikue Mori, Butch Morris, Joe Morris, Marc Ribot, Matana Roberts, Jamie Saft, Chris Speed, Jason Stein, Otomo Yoshihide and John Zorn.

BRANDON WOZNIAK (saxophone) is based in Minneapolis, MN and a member of the following bands: Dave King Trucking Company, Wailing Ships, Atlantis Quartet, Bryan Nichols Quintet, Parker Paisley, Chris Bates Quintet and from time to time a few others. Brandon studied music at Indiana University and then moved to New York to listen and practice for 6 years while trying to forget everything he learned at college. Brandon was once in a German rock band and lived in Berlin Germany for seven months trying to pay off his student loans playing rock shows. That didn't work but Brandon had a great time in Berlin. Brandon then moved to Shanghai China to play jazz in clubs and hotels where he got to sample many fine cigars through second hand smoke. Brandon has lived and worked in Minneapolis since 2006 and hopes to continue playing music forever.
ADAM LINZ (bass) is a well-known bass player in the Twin Cities jazz scene. He co-leads the internationally award-winning group Fat Kid Wednesdays with childhood friends Mike Lewis and JT Bates, touring extensively throughout Europe and North America. Adam has taught at Macalester College, Augsburg College, Minnesota Institute for Talented Youth and EDAM Music outreach in Paris, and has given clinics in places such as Chile, Argentina, Seattle, New York, Houston, Germany, and Switzerland. Adam has performed with such jazz greats as Evan Parker, Stanley Turretine, Milt Jackson and electronic artist Dosh. He has a Bachelor of Music from the William Paterson University Jazz Studies program.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Obviously we only have a limited time frame to execute this (this will not be a "Chinese Democracy"-type sprawling process!), so we have to be very focused in the studio so we can get it tracked in two days. Once everyone goes home, that's it, and the mixing process begins. This limited time-frame does not worry me because the level of the talent I am working with is unparalleled; these three players are incredible readers, improvisors, and listeners. I am also taking our limited time frame into account with the writing - making sure I'm not composing anything that would require more than a few hours of group rehearsal, and getting charts and scratch demos to the players well ahead of time. We are also playing a performance at Elastic Arts in Chicago before we enter the studio, which will be an ideal "trial by fire" opportunity to test and temper the music. I am confident it will come together beautifully!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content: Woah nelly, this has really taken off in the last 24 hours! I'm leaving for Minnesota tomorrow to begin rehearsals with Adam and Brandon, and I am feeling a strong tailwind from the awesome boost this kickstarter has gotten. All of you that have helped me promote it - huge thanks! You are the reason I've seen this blow up today. Less than 24 hours left, and I am hoping to see it get a little farther! Every penny counts and will be put to good use in the process of making my record! Love- Luke

Hey friends! So this kickstarter thing has really worked out beautifully for me. I'm $300 past my goal and still have four days to get even farther. I am hoping to get it up to $3000, which would offset some of the "hidden" costs of this project like, oh, paying my musicians! I also have mastering fees to work out, paying for the design and typesetting of the artwork and booklet, and lots of other little things that add up to a chunk of money. So spread the word if you know some friends that wanted to chip in but reconsidered after seeing me hit the goal so fast! Thanks again, Luke

updates.update_userinfo: 4 days to go! Keep it rocking!
updates.update_content:
Hey guys and gals!
We are making great progress towards my goal; in just 4 days I have raised $1,364, which is 62% of my $2200 goal! The average pledge is about $42, with most people pre-ordering the CD and a handful of awesome folks going "all-in" for the private concert! I am working hard on editing, engraving, and actually learning how to play my music now, and it is really sound good. I can't wait to hear how this will all sound with the band playing it.
Not even 24 hours in and I'm at 45% of my target - I am really floored at people's generosity and belief in this project! Thank you all so much for being a part of my album!

campaign.story:
Dancer/choreographer Bridget Breiner and her brother, saxophonist Patrick Breiner have dreamed of creating a dance piece together for years. In May of 2011 the two came together to perform a short piece called "Come Again When You Can't Stay So Long" in remembrance of their late grandfather, Dick Breiner. Now they're upping the ante. This major collaboration between the siblings has been a long time coming.
Bridget's new position as the artistic director of Ballett im Revier in Gelsenkirchen, Germany presents the pair with a new and exciting opportunity: to create a brand new dance piece on a large scale.
The Breiners, in this case, act largely as catalysts: Bridget inviting the dancers and choreographers of Ballett im Revier and Patrick inviting his closest musical and compositional compatriots, Aaron Darrell and Devin Drobka of Sons Of Daughters.
The dancers and musicians will work together in Gelsenkirchen for two weeks in October. They will explore the themes of hero/anti-hero while developing a unique improvisational language between musician and dancer. This collaboration will culminate on October 27, 2012 with the performance of the new dance piece: Jam Session.
Ballett im Revier is providing Sons Of Daughters with a modest stipend, but our travel expenses to and from Germany will not be covered. This is where you come in. We need the support of the community in order to make this dream a reality.
We're offering a number of enticing rewards for your contribution. Please peruse the options at right.
Dancers/choreographers of Jam Session include:
Joe Bunn
Junior Demitre
Maiko Arai
Sons Of Daughters

updates.update_content:
Jam Session supporters!
SoD has been hard at work this week with some unbelievable dancers and choreographers at Ballett im Revier, and we have a tasty little something to show for it. Photo updates can be found on our blog here: www.SonsOfDaughters.Tumblr.com. Believe me, this is only the beginning.
Also, if you haven't already, please "like" us on facebook to stay in the loop: www.facebook.com/SonsOfDaughters

Esteemed Kickstarter Backers
It's day 5 here in Gelsenkirchen for my body. It must be about day 3 or 3.5 for my brain (it came in on a later flight).
Aaron and Devin arrive a week from today and I'm incredibly excited to have my musical foils close at hand again. I'm hard at work writing music in preparation for their arrival. One piece in particular is being written for a part of choreographed by Marika Carena.

Ladies and gents, we've done it! We've achieved our goal and then some. Thank you thank you thank you thank you for your love and support. We're excited about this new opportunity and what it means for our group and our music.
That being said, we've still got 53 hours left. Let's bump it up over $3,000!

We already made and gave away one starring Devin Drobka, and it's a scream! See below. We love you all madly.

updates.update_userinfo: Next 5 backers at $25 or more get a digital download of SoD Duo (Breiner/Drobka) at Birkfest this past weekend!
updates.update_content:
Just what it sounds like. Breiner and Drobka just finished up a duo tour and have never sounded better. This 40 minute set includes performances of Paul Motian tunes "The Owl of Cranston" and "Mesmer," Breiner's "Unfinished Business," the world premier of Drobka's "Jake's Theme," and LOTS of improvising. Not to mention some well timed interjections by an amazing thunderstorm. Come and get it!
Here's a little taste of "The Owl of Cranston."

campaign.story:
The Zodiac Ensemble is a Brooklyn, NY based jazz and new music group.  At its core are three natives of Stevens Point, WI:  reedsmen Aaron Kruziki and Mike Bjella, and bassist Karl McComas-Reichl.  Esteemed pianist Glenn Zaleski and acclaimed drummer Colin Stranahan round out the starting lineup.  
After a tour in June of 2011, we went into Tedesco Studios in Paramus, NJ to record our debut album.  It’s a full length record of all original material, and it’s been mixed and mastered.  The artwork is ready.  We are very excited to share it with the world, but we need your help to turn these elements into real, living, breathing albums that you can hold in your hands!   
We will use most of the funds raised to press the album.  A portion will go to the engineer who mixed and mastered the album, and the rest will be used for promotion.
If you’re unfamiliar with our music, check out some video of the aforementioned tour, or have a listen to a sampler track.  You're the best!
